revision.text:
{{distinguish|stock footage}} {{main|Filmmaking|Video production}} [[File:B-roll of Wikimedia Foundation servers at CyrusOne in Carrollton, Texas - photographed in 2015.webm|thumb|right|200px|several minutes of B-roll of computer servers]] {{wiktionary|B roll}}
In film and television production, '''B-roll''', '''B roll''', '''B-reel''' or '''B reel''' is supplemental or alternative [[footage]] intercut with the main shot.<ref name="Bowen and Thompson 2011">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Rl7IyLPt5ucC&pg=PA240 |page=240 |last=Bowen |first=Christopher J. |last2=Thompson |first2=Roy |title=Grammar of the Shot |publisher=Taylor & Francis |date=2011 |isbn=9780240526010}}</ref> The term ''A-roll'' referring to the main footage has fallen out of usage.<ref name="Compesi and Gomez 2014"/>
==Film and video production== Films and videos may [[Cutaway (filmmaking)|cut away from the main story]] to show related scenery or action. [[Establishing shot]]s may be used to show the audience the context of the story. These secondary images are often presented without sound, as the sound from the primary footage is expected to continue while the other images are shown. The various shots presented without sound are called ''B-roll''.<ref name="Irving and Rea 2014">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6pvcAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA172 |page=172 |title=Producing and Directing the Short Film and Video |first1=David K. |last1=Irving |first2=Peter W. |last2=Rea |publisher=CRC Press |year=2014 |isbn=9781136048425}}</ref>
B-roll may be shot by smaller [[second unit]] crews, since there is no need for sound. In film, smaller [[MOS (filmmaking)|MOS]] cameras may be used for greater portability and ease of setup.<ref name="Irving and Rea 2014"/> In [[electronic news-gathering]] (ENG) and [[documentary film]] projects, B-roll footage is often shot after the main interview is shot, to provide supporting scenes for what was said by the interview subject.<ref name="Compesi and Gomez 2014">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K5vhCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA268 |page=268 |last=Compesi |first=Ronald |last2=Gomez |title=Introduction to Video Production: Studio, Field, and Beyond |publisher=CRC Press |date=2015 |isbn=9781317347156}}</ref> In a [[docudrama]] project, B-roll may refer to dramatic re-enactment scenes staged by the producer and performed by actors, to be used as cutaway shots.<ref name=Wales2017>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=giglDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA17 |page=17 |last=Wales |first=Lorena M. |title=The Complete Guide to Film and Digital Production: The People and The Process |publisher=Taylor & Francis |date=2017 |isbn=9781315294889}}</ref>
B-roll footage may be added to or drawn from a [[stock footage]] library.<ref name="Bowen and Thompson 2011"/><ref name=Wales2017/>
==History== ===16 mm film splices=== The term ''B-roll'' originates from a particular solution to the problem of visible splices in the narrow [[film stock]] used in [[16 mm film]]. 35 mm film was wide enough to hide splices, but 16 mm film revealed the splices as flaws in the picture. To avoid this problem, the intended shots were spliced to [[Film leader|opaque black leader]], with the black leader hiding the splice. Two sequences of shots were assembled, the odd-numbered shots on the A-roll, and the even-numbered shots on the B-roll, such that all of the shots on one roll were matched by black leader on the other roll, in a checkerboard pattern (an alternate name for the process was "checkerboard printing".) Unexposed 16 mm raw print stock was [[Exposure (photography)|exposed]] twice, once to the A-roll, then it was exposed again to the B-roll.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3NFAbjYD8MkC&pg=PA669 |page=669 |title=The Filmmaker's Handbook: A Comprehensive Guide for the Digital Age |first=Steven |last=Ascher |first2=Edward |last2=Pincus |publisher=Penguin |date=2007 |isbn=9780452286788}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WRklp-TmfQkC&pg=PA108 |page=108 |title=Film Technology in Post Production |first=Dominic |last=Case |publisher=Taylor & Francis |date=April 26, 2013 |isbn=9781136049781}}</ref><ref>Spottiswoode, Raymond (1966), ''Film and its techniques''. U. Cal Press. Chapter 1, p 44.</ref>
===Telecine transfer=== Until the mid-1970s, ENG teams shot both main A-roll and secondary B-roll footage on 16 mm film. [[Sound on film|Sound was integrated onto the film]] by way of a magnetic stripe at the edge of the film. The A-roll and B-roll scenes, shot at 24 frames per second, were converted to the television frame rate of 30 fps using a [[telecine]] system consisting of two film projectors, one showing the main A-roll footage and the other showing the B-roll. The sound from the A-roll footage was used, or sound from narration or voiceover, while MOS images from the B-roll were intercut as desired.<ref name="Compesi and Gomez 2014"/>
===Linear video tape editing=== In the 1980s, the term ''B-roll'' was adopted for [[linear video editing]] using at least two video tape machines. Traditionally, the [[Tape recorder|tape decks]] in an edit suite were labeled by letter, with the 'A' deck being the one containing the main tape upon which the main action material was shot. The 'B' deck was used to run tapes that held additional footage such as establishing shots, cutaway shots, and any other supporting footage. The sound was usually taken from the A deck alone, so that the B deck provided video without sound.<ref name="Irving and Rea 2014"/> As linear editing systems were unable to dissolve between clips on the same tape, an [[edit decision list]] (EDL) was used to mark clips as "A-roll" and "B-roll" to indicate source machines.

{{redirect|Bachmut|the Bachmut meteorite of 1814|Meteorite falls}} {{Infobox settlement | name = Bakhmut | native_name = Бахмут | settlement_type = [[City of regional significance (Ukraine)|City of regional significance]] | image_skyline = File:Панорама міста Артемівськ 77.JPG | image_caption = Bakhmut skyline | image_flag = Flag of Artemivsk (Donetsk Oblast).svg | image_shield = Coat of Arms of Bakhmut.svg | image_map = | pushpin_map= Ukraine Donetsk Oblast#Ukraine | pushpin_label_position = bottom | coordinates = {{coord|48|35|29|N|38|4|50|E|region:UA|display=inline,title}} | subdivision_type = [[Countries of the world|Country]] | subdivision_name = {{UKR}} | subdivision_type1 = [[Oblast]] | subdivision_type2 = | subdivision_name1 = {{flag|Donetsk Oblast}} | subdivision_name2 = | established_title = Founded | established_date = before 1571 | established_title1 = City rights | established_date1 = 1783http://artemrada.gov.ua/uk/history/ | total_type =   | area_total_km2 = 41.6 | elevation_m = 200 | population_total = 77,177 | population_as_of =2015 | website = | blank_name = [[Köppen climate classification|Climate]] | blank_info = [[Humid continental climate#Mild/cool summer subtype|Dfb]] }} '''Bakhmut''' ({{lang-uk|Ба́хмут}}, {{lang-ru|Бахмут}}) formerly '''Artemivsk/Artyomovsk''' ({{lang-uk|Артемівськ|links=no}}, {{lang-ru|Артёмовск|links=no}}), is a [[City of regional significance (Ukraine)|city of regional significance]] in [[Donetsk Oblast]], [[Ukraine]]. On 4 February 2016 the [[Verkhovna Rada]] of Ukraine confirmed the name change of the city by returning to the original one.[http://www.unian.info/society/1255225-decommunisation-continues-rada-renames-several-towns-and-villages.html Decommunisation continues: Rada renames several towns and villages], [[UNIAN]] (4 February 2016){{cite web|url=http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2016/02/4/7097833/|title=Rada de-communized Artemivsk as well as over hundred cities and villages|date=4 February 2016|publisher=[[Ukrayinska Pravda]]|language=Ukrainian|accessdate=4 February 2016}} The city serves as an [[administrative center]] of [[Bakhmut Raion]] although it does not belong to the raion. It is located on the Bakhmutka River about 89 km away from the administrative center of the Donetsk Oblast, [[Donetsk]]. Population: {{Ua-pop-est2015|77,177}} Bakhmut was a capital of [[Slavo-Serbia]], which was established by Austrian migrants from Serbia. In 1920–24, the city was an administrative center of [[Donets Governorate]] of the [[Ukrainian SSR]]. [[File:Artyomovsk01.jpg|thumb|Freedom Square in Bakhmut]] [[File:Женская гимназия им. Екатерины Великой.JPG|thumb|Former gymnasium]] [[File:Земуправа.JPG|thumb|Railway institute building]] [[File:Путиловский банк.JPG|thumb|Old bank building]] [[File:Федоренко. артемовск27.jpg|thumb|Downtown Bakhmut]] [[File:Федоренко. артемовск29.jpg|thumb|City council]] [[File:Artemivsk 01.jpg|thumb|Soviet-built microdistrict]] ==History== There is evidence of prior settlement in 1556. However, officially it was founded in 1571 and named as Bakhmut fort after the river Bakhmutka (a tributary of the [[Seversky Donets River|Seversky Donets]]) on which it is situated. The settlement initially began as a border point and was later turned into a fortification. The name derived from Tatar name Mahmud or Mahmet. In 1701, [[Peter the Great|Peter I]] ordered to build a fort and rename the town from Bahmut to Bakhmut. The fort was completed in 1703. In 1704 Peter the Great issued a ukase permitting Cossacks to settle in Bakhmut. In the autumn of 1705, a detachment of [[Cossacks]] headed by Ataman [[Kondraty Bulavin]] captured the Bakhmut salt mines,[http://www.krugosvet.ru/enc/istoriya/VOSSTANIE_KRESTYAN_I_KAZAKOV_POD_RUKOVODSTVOM_KONDRATIYA_AFANASEVICHA_BULAVINA.html Rebellion of peasants and Cossacks under the leadership of Bulavin] {{ru icon}} which later caused the town to be one of the centers of the [[Bulavin Rebellion]], and held the city until March 7, 1708 when it was seized by government troops. From 1708 to April 22, 1725, Bakhmut is situated in the [[Azov Governorate]], and on May 29, 1719 becomes the administrative center of Bakhmut Province within the governorate.{{cite web|url=http://www.history.org.ua/?termin=Bakhmutska_provintsiia|title=Інститут історії України НАН України|work=history.org.ua|accessdate=9 February 2015}} From 1753 to 1764, it was a main city of the [[Slavo-Serbia]] territory inhabited by colonists from [[Serbia]] and elsewhere. In 1783, Bakhmut received city status within the Yekaterinoslav province ([[Novorossiysk Governorate]]).{{cite book|title=Brockhaus and Efron Encyclopedia Dictionary|year=1903|author=|publisher=|page=|url=| isbn= |language=ru}} During this time, in the city, there were 49 houses, five brick, candle, and soap factories. The city had about 150 shops, a hospital, and three schools: two private boarding schools for children of wealthy parents, and a Sunday school for children of workers. Bakhmut had a large shopping center. There twice a year, on July 12 (Day of the Apostles Peter and Paul) and September 21 (Day of the Nativity of the Blessed Virgin Mary), big fairs were conducted. The city's annual turnover was about 1 million rubles. On August 2, 1811, the city emblem was approved. In 1875, a water-system was installed. On January 25, 1851, the city became a municipality, with Vasily I. Pershin as mayor. In 1876, within the Bakhmut Basin were discovered large deposits of rock salt, which was followed by a rapid increase in the numbers of mines, with salt productions reaching 12% nationwide. After the construction of a rail route Kharkov-Bakhmut-Popasnaya, there was enterprise for the production of [[alabaster]], [[plaster]], [[brick]], [[tile]], and [[soda ash]]. At the beginning of the twentieth century, the city developed metal-working. By 1900, the city had 76 small industrial enterprises, which employed 1,078 workers, as well as four [[salt mines]], which employed 874 workers. In 1900, the streets became paved. By 1913, the population consisted of 28,000 people. There were two hospitals with 210 beds, four secondary and two vocational schools, six single-class schools, four parish schools, and a private library. In April 1918 troops loyal to the [[Ukrainian People's Republic]] took control of Bakhmut.{{uk icon}} [http://www.istpravda.com.ua/short/2018/04/18/152320/ 100 years ago Bakhmut and the rest of Donbass liberated], [[Ukrayinska Pravda]] (18 April 2018) On December 27, 1919, Soviet power is established within the city. In 1923, there were 36 enterprises, including a factory "Victory of Labor" (a former nail-spike factory), a factory "Lightning" that produced castings for agriculture, as well as brick, tile, and alabaster factories; mines "Karl Liebknecht and Sverdlov", "Shevchenko", and "Bakhmut salt"; and a shoe factory. From April 16, 1920 to August 1, 1925, Bakhmut is the administrative center of the Donetsk province. In 1924 the city's name was changed from Bakhmut to '''Artemivsk''', in honour of [[Fyodor Sergeyev|Artyom]], a Russian [[Bolshevik]] (Communist) revolutionary figure who lived and worked in the city in the early years of the revolution. In 1938, Moskalenko is the First Secretary of the Municipal Committee of the CPU. In 1941, Vasily Panteleevich Prokopenko is First Secretary of the City Committee of the Communist Party. From October 31, 1941 to May 9, 1943, German troops occupied Artemivsk under the command of Von Zobel. Under occupation in 1941, Nikolai Mikhailovich Zhorov is Secretary of the underground City Party Committee. In 1961, Kuzma Petrovich Golovko became First Secretary of City Party Committee, followed by Ivan Malyukin in 1966, Nikolai S. Tagan in 1976, and Yuri K. Smirnov from 1980 to 1983. From April 1990 to 1994, Alexei Reva was Chairman of City Council and was elected mayor in 1994.[http://whp057.narod.ru/artemovsk.htm A chronological list of events in the history of Artemovsk] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081030073957/http://whp057.narod.ru/artemovsk.htm |date=2008-10-30 }} {{ru icon}} During the [[2014 pro-Russian unrest in Ukraine]], the militants of [[Donetsk People's Republic]] declared the city part of the republic by [[2014 insurgency in Donbass|pro-Russian separatists]].{{cite web|url=https://newrepublic.com/article/117387/putin-accidentally-helping-unite-eastern-and-western-ukraine|title=Putin Is Accidentally Helping Unite Eastern and Western Ukraine - The New Republic|author=Leonid Ragozin|work=The New Republic|accessdate=9 February 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://en.itar-tass.com/world/735082|title=TASS: World - Donbass defenders put WWII tank back into service|work=TASS|accessdate=9 February 2015}} The city was eventually retaken by Ukrainian forces on 7 July 2014, along with [[Druzhkivka]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-28191833|title=BBC News - Ukraine crisis: Bridges destroyed outside Donetsk|work=BBC News|accessdate=9 February 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/212315.html|title=Ukraine flag raised over two cities, military tells Poroshenko|work=Interfax-Ukraine|accessdate=9 February 2015}} On 15 May 2015 [[President of Ukraine]] [[Petro Poroshenko]] signed a bill into law that started a six months period for the [[Decommunization in Ukraine|removal of communist monuments and the mandatory renaming of settlements]] with a name related to [[Communism]].[http://www.pravda.com.ua/news/2015/05/15/7068057/ Poroshenko signed the laws about decomunization]. [[Ukrayinska Pravda]]. 15 May 2015
[http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/general/265988.html Poroshenko signs laws on denouncing Communist, Nazi regimes], [[Interfax-Ukraine]]. 15 May 20
[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-32267075 Goodbye, Lenin: Ukraine moves to ban communist symbols], [[BBC News]] (14 April 2015) On 23 September 2015 the city council voted for renaming the city back to Bakhmut (for - 31, against - 8, abstain - 3, did not vote - 3).[https://web.archive.org/web/20150923150638/http://artemrada.gov.ua/uk/news/10260 Renaming city and streets]. Artemivsk city council website. 23 September 2015 The final decision was made by the [[Verkhovna Rada]] (Supreme Council of Ukraine) on 4 February 2016. ===Name change=== * 1571 - 1924 Bakhmut * 1924 - 1941 Artyomovsk / Artemivsk (Artemivsk until 1930s) * 1942 - 1943 Bakhmut{{citation needed|date=February 2016}} * 1943 - 1992 Artyomovsk / Artemivsk * 1992 - 2016 Artemivsk * 2016–present Bakhmut ==Demographics== As of June 1, 2017 the population of Bakhmut was 75.9 thousand people[http://bahmut.com.ua/news/society/5183-kolichestvo-zhiteley-bahmuta-prodolzhaet-sokraschatsya.html "Количество жителей Бахмута продолжает сокращаться"] Vecherniy Bakhmut, September 5, 2017. According to the [[Ukrainian Census (2001)|Ukrainian Census of 2001]], the majority of residents are ethnic Ukrainians and speak Russian as a first language:[https://www.webcitation.org/6CURge2tu?url=http://donetskstat.gov.ua/census/census.php?ncp=11&ncp1=6 Національний склад та рідна мова населення Донецької області. Розподіл постійного населення за найбільш численними національностями та рідною мовою по міськрадах та районах.]{{cite web|url=http://www.ukrcensus.gov.ua|title=Ukrcensus.gov.ua|work=ukrcensus.gov.ua|accessdate=9 February 2015}} {| class="standard" | align="center" style="background:#f0f0f0;"| '''Ethnicity''' | align="center" style="background:#f0f0f0;"| |- | Ukrainians ||69.4% |- | Russians ||27.5% |- | Belarusians ||0.6% |- | Armenians ||0.3% |- | Roma ||0.2% |- | Jews ||0.2% |} {| class="standard" | align="center" style="background:#f0f0f0;"| '''Language''' | align="center" style="background:#f0f0f0;"| |- | [[Russian language|Russian]] ||71.07% |- | [[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]] ||27.61% |- | [[Armenian language|Armenian]] || 0.19% |- | [[Romani language|Romani]] ||0.15% |- | [[Belarusian language|Belarusian]] ||0.10% |} ==Economy== [[File:АЗШВ.jpg|thumb|Bakhmut Winery]] Since 1951, the European Bakhmut Winery is located in the city. The Artyomsol [[salt mine]] is located in the suburb of [[Soledar]], which contains the world's largest underground room. It is large enough that a [[hot air balloon]] has been floated inside, [[Symphony|symphonies]] have been played before, and two [[professional]] [[soccer]] matches have been held at the same time. It is large enough to fit [[Notre Dame de Paris|Notre Dame]] inside with room to spare. ===Transport=== [[File:Южный вок.JPG|thumb|Bakhmut-1 railway station]] The highways of [[Kharkiv]]-[[Rostov]] and [[Donetsk]]-[[Kiev]] run through Bakhmut. The towns of [[Chasiv Yar]] and [[Soledar]] are included in the Bakhmut municipality. The city has a [[public transport]] system consisting of a network of trolleybuses and buses. ==Education== There are 20 schools (11,600 students), 29 kindergartens (3500 children), 4 vocational schools (2,000 students), 2 technical schools (6,000 students), and several music schools. Some include: * Artemovsk Industrial College (Tchaikovsky Street) * Donetsk Musical College named John Karabits (Lermontov Street) * Donetsk Pedagogical School (St. Annunciation) * Donetsk Medical School (St. W. Nosakova) * Artemovsk professional school (St. Defence) ==Culture== * Artemovsk City Center Children and Youth (Artema Street) * Artemovsk city center of culture and recreation (Svoboda) * Artemovsk City Folk House (Victory Street) * Building Technology "Donetskgeologiya" (St. Sibirtzev) * Palace of Culture "mechanician" (Artema Street) ==See also== * [[Bulavin Rebellion]] * [[:ru:Кропотов, Гаврила Семёнович]] * [[:ru:Шидловские]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Wikisource1911Enc|Bakhmut}} * {{en icon}} [http://www.encyclopediaofukraine.com/display.asp?linkpath=pages%5CA%5CR%5CArtemivskDonetskoblast.htm Artemivsk] at the [[Encyclopedia of Ukraine]] * {{ru icon}} [http://www.art.dn.ua/ City portal] * {{uk icon}} [http://www.history.org.ua/?termin=Artemivsk_mst Encyclopedia of History of Ukraine] * {{uk icon}} [http://artemrada.gov.ua/ City council website] {{Bakhmut municipality}} {{Donetsk Oblast}} {{2014 pro-Russian conflict in Ukraine}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Cities in Donetsk Oblast]] [[Category:Yekaterinoslav Governorate]] [[Category:Populated places established in 1571]] [[Category:Mining cities and regions in Ukraine]] [[Category:Russification]] [[Category:Cities of regional significance in Ukraine]] [[Category:City name changes in Ukraine]] [[Category:Former Soviet toponymy in Ukraine]] [[Category:1571 establishments in Europe]] [[Category:Cities and towns built in the Sloboda Ukraine]]

revision.text: #REDIRECT [[Cabin (ship)#Modern warships]] [[Category:Nautical terminology]] [[Category:Ship compartments]]

The '''captain of the port''' is an official who has different functions in the [[United Kingdom]], the [[United States]], and other countries.
To some extent the role of captain of the port is analogous to that of a [[harbourmaster]].
==United Kingdom== In the [[Royal Navy]], the captain of the port was the officer, usually with the rank of [[Captain (Royal Navy)|captain]], responsible for the day-to-day running of a [[Royal Navy Dockyard|Naval Dockyard]] under the authority of the [[admiral-superintendent]]. He usually also held the position of [[Queen's Harbourmaster|Queen's or King's harbourmaster]] and was directly responsible for the captain's department, which among other things operated the [[Admiralty Yard Craft Service|yard craft]].
From the 1650s until the mid-nineteenth century the position was known as '''master attendant''', and ranked immediately below that of Navy Commissioner. Occupants of the office were required to be "skilful in all affairs requisite in the looking after, equipping and setting out of State ships", for which they initially received an annual wage of between £90 and £100 plus accommodation.<ref>Hammond 1974, p. 119</ref> The office was often combined with that of harbourmaster, and existed until the second half of the 19th century, when occupants (in common with Royal Naval [[Sailing Master|masters]]) began to be commissioned with the rank of staff captain. From the early twentieth century the equivalent appointment became '''staff captain (dockyard)''', then '''captain of the dockyard''', and finally captain of the port from 1969.
==United States== {{main|Sector Commander}} In the United States, captain of the port (COTP) is a title held by a [[United States Coast Guard]] officer, usually the [[Sector Commander|commander]] of a [[United States Coast Guard Sectors|United States Coast Guard sector]] with the rank of captain (O-6). Captain of the port duties involve enforcing within their respective areas port safety and security and marine environmental protection regulations, including regulations for the protection and security of vessels, harbors, and waterfront facilities; anchorages; security zones; safety zones; regulated navigation areas; deepwater ports; water pollution; and ports and waterways safety.<ref>[http://ecfr.gpoaccess.gov/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=ecfr&rgn=div8&view=text&node=33:1.0.1.1.1.1.1.3&idno=33 Title 33, Code Federal Regulations, Part 1.01-30] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613090551/http://ecfr.gpoaccess.gov/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=ecfr&rgn=div8&view=text&node=33%3A1.0.1.1.1.1.1.3&idno=33 |date=June 13, 2011 }}</ref> ==References== {{reflist}}
===Bibliography=== *{{cite thesis |last=Hammond|first=Wayne Neil |date=27 March 1974|title=The Administration of the English Navy, 1649-1660 |publisher=University of British Columbia |oclc=15754886}} {{US Coast Guard navbox}}
[[Category:Royal Navy appointments]] [[Category:United States Coast Guard job titles]] [[Category:Nautical terminology]] [[Category:Port authorities|*]]

'''Catabiosis''' is the process of growing older, [[aging]] and physical degradation.
The word comes from Greek "kata"—down, against, reverse and "biosis"—way of life and is generally used to describe [[senescence]] and [[Degeneration (medical)|degeneration]] in living organisms and [[biophysics]] of aging in general.
One of the popular catabiotic theories is the [[entropy]] theory of aging, where aging is characterized by thermodynamically favourable increase in structural disorder. Living organisms are [[Thermodynamic system#Open system|open systems]] that take [[Thermodynamic free energy|free energy]] from the environment and offload their entropy as waste. However, basic components of living systems—[[DNA]], [[proteins]], [[lipids]] and [[sugars]]—tend towards the state of maximum entropy while continuously accumulating damages causing catabiosis of the living structure.
[[Catabiotic force]] on the contrary is the influence exerted by living structures on adjoining cells, by which the latter are developed in harmony with the primary structures.
== See also == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070311151036/http://www.onpedia.com/dictionary/catabiosis Onpedia definition of catabiosis] *[http://www.thefreedictionary.com/Catabiotic+force Catabiotic force] *[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/catabiosis Dictionary.com - Catabiosis] *[[DNA damage theory of aging]]
{{senescence}}
[[Category:Medical aspects of death]] [[Category:Biology terminology]] [[Category:Senescence]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox writer <!-- For more information see [[:Template:Infobox Writer/doc]]. --> | name = Chandravadan Chimanlal Mehta | image = ChandravadanMehtaPic.jpg | birth_date = {{Birth date|df=yes|1901|04|06}} | birth_place = [[Surat]], [[British India]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1991|04|05|1901|04|06}} | occupation = Playwright, critic, autobiograpger, poet, broadcaster, travel writer | language = Gujarati | nationality = Indian | residence = [[Vadodara]] | education = [[Bachelor of Arts|B. A.]] | notableworks = ''Natya Gathariyan'' | spouse = {{marriage |Vilas |1925 |1938 |end=divorced}} | awards = {{plainlist| * [[Padma Shri]] (1962) * [[Sahitya Academy Award]] (1971) * [[List of Sangeet Natak Akademi fellows|Sangeet Natak Akademi Fellowship]] (1984)}} }} '''Chandravadan Chimanlal Mehta''' (6 April 1901 – 4 May 1991), popularly known as '''C. C. Mehta''' or '''Chan. Chi. Mehta''',<ref name="gsp"/> was a [[Gujarati language|Gujarati]] playwright, theatre critic, bibliographer, poet, story writer, autobiographer, travel writer and broadcaster from [[Vadodara]], [[Gujarat]], India.
==Life== Chandravadan Mehta was born on 6 April 1901 in [[Surat]].<ref name="gsp">{{cite web|url=http://gujaratisahityaparishad.com/prakashan/sarjako/savishesh/Savishesh-Cha-Chi-Mehta.html|title=ચંદ્રવદન મહેતા|last=Topiwala|first=Chandrakant|authorlink=Chandrakant Topiwala|date=|website=|publisher=[[Gujarati Sahitya Parishad]]|language=gu|trans-title=Chandravadan Mehta|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111107002845/http://gujaratisahityaparishad.com/prakashan/sarjako/savishesh/Savishesh-Cha-Chi-Mehta.html|archive-date=7 November 2011|dead-url=no|access-date=|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="ox">{{Cite book|url=http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/acref/9780195644463.001.0001/acref-9780195644463-e-0351#|title=The Oxford Companion to Indian Theatre|last=Lal|first=Ananda|date=|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2004|isbn=9780199861248|location=New Delhi|pages=|oclc=607157336|via=Oxford Reference|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612054215/http://www.oxfordreference.com/view/10.1093/acref/9780195644463.001.0001/acref-9780195644463-e-0351|archivedate=12 June 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> His primary education was in [[Vadodara]] and secondary education in Surat.<ref name="gsp"/> He matriculated in 1919 and completed [[Bachelor of Arts|B. A.]] in Gujarati from the [[Elphinstone College]], [[Bombay]] (now Mumbai) in 1924. In 1928, he joined [[Mahatma Gandhi]] in the [[Bardoli Satyagraha]]. He also joined ''Navbharat'' daily as an editor in 1928. From 1933 to 1936, he taught at New Era High School, Mumbai.<ref name="gsp"/><ref name="Te2003"/><ref name="ox"/>
He joined the [[All India Radio]] (AIR)-Bombay in 1938 and became the director of AIR-[[Ahmedabad]] in 1954. During his tenure, he developed the broadcasting culture in Gujarat, wrote and produced several radio plays and documentaries with directors like Adi Marzban and others.<ref name="ox"/> After retirement, he was associated with the performing arts departments of the [[Maharaja Sayajirao University of Baroda]] and the [[Gujarat Vidyapith]].<ref name="gsp"/><ref name="Te2003"/> He pioneered the theatre education in India and started diploma and degree courses in theatre in the Maharaja Sayajirao University of Baroda. He represented India in the international theatre fora.<ref name="ox"/>
He married Vilas in 1925. They separated by divorces in 1938.<ref name=":0">{{cite thesis|last=Patel|first=Kanaiyalal L.|title=નાટ્યકાર ક. મા. મુનશી અને ચંદ્રવદન ચી મહેતાના સામાજિક નાટકોનો વિશ્લેષણાત્મક અભ્યાસ|date=31 July 1999|degree=Ph. D.|publisher=Department of Gujarati, [[Gujarat University]]|url=http://shodhganga.inflibnet.ac.in/handle/10603/47093|doi=|language=gu|trans-title=Analytical Study of the Social Plays Written by K. M. Munshi and C. C. Mehta|year=1999|type=Ph.D|location=Ahmedabad|page=173, Appendix p. 9}}</ref> He died on 5 April 1991.<ref name="ox"/><ref name=":0" />
==Works== Mehta is considered as the pioneer of the modern [[Gujarati theatre]].<ref name="ox"/> His plays are focused on the stagecraft which has diversity of subjects including tragedy, comedy, satire as well as historical, social, mythological, biographical plays.<ref name="gsp"/> ;Theatre and plays In early 1920, he presented two unscripted soliloquies which created a stir. He criticized and led a protest against the depiction of women in ''College Kanya'' (College Girl, 1925) , a play produced by the Mumbai Gujarati Natak Mandali.<ref name="ox"/>
Mehta wrote over 25 plays, numerous [[one-act play]]s and radio plays.<ref name="George1992">{{cite book|author=K. M. George|title=Modern Indian Literature, an Anthology: Plays and prose|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eTXougCB-NMC&pg=PA179|year=1992|publisher=Sahitya Akademi|isbn=978-81-7201-783-5|page=179|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612054215/https://books.google.com/books?id=eTXougCB-NMC&pg=PA179|archivedate=12 June 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> He, along with his friends, wrote and produced several realistic plays such as ''Akho'' (1927), ''Agagadi'' (1933, translated as ''Iron Road'' in 1970), ''Narmad'' (1937) and ''Dhara Gurjari'' (Land of Gujarat, 1944, published 1968).<ref name="ox"/> ''Aagagadi'', about an ailing fireman, marked the rise of amateur theatre movement in the [[Gujarati theatre]].<ref name="HochmanStaff1984">{{cite book|author1=Stanley Hochman|author2=McGraw-Hill Staff|title=McGraw-Hill Encyclopedia of World Drama: An International Reference Work in 5 Volumes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zo5os6d0rvMC&pg=PA38|year=1984|publisher=VNR AG|isbn=978-0-07-079169-5|page=38}}</ref><ref name="Chambers2006">{{cite book|author=Colin Chambers|title=Continuum Companion to Twentieth Century Theatre|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=cFlFhuVMFGQC&pg=PA382|date=14 May 2006|publisher=A&C Black|isbn=978-1-84714-001-2|page=382|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612054215/https://books.google.com/books?id=cFlFhuVMFGQC&pg=PA382|archivedate=12 June 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref name="Te2003">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AbLPU10RFUYC&pg=PA100|title=C. C. Mehta|author=Shailesh Tevani|first=|publisher=Sahitya Akademi|year=2003|isbn=978-81-260-1676-1|series=Makers of Indian Literature|location=|page=|pages=50, 87, 92|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180612054215/https://books.google.com/books?id=AbLPU10RFUYC&pg=PA100|archivedate=12 June 2018|df=dmy-all}}</ref> His other published plays include ''Mungi Stree'' (1927), ''Akho, Varvahu ane Bija Natako'' (1933), ''Ramakadani Dukan'' (1934), ''Nagabava'' (1937), ''Premnu Moti Ane Bija Natako'' (1937), ''Sita'' (1943), ''Mazamrat'' (Dark Mindnight, 1955), ''Hololika'' (1956, published 1957) and ''Savitri''- a dramatization of [[Sri Aurobindo]]'s ''[[Savitri (book)|Savitri]]''. ''Hololika'' was in format of [[Bhavai]], a traditional Gujarati theatre.<ref name="ox"/> He also published following plays: ''Shikharini'' (1946), ''Panjarapol'' (1947), ''Mena Popat Athva Hathighoda'' (1951), ''Rangbhandar'' (1953), ''Sonavatakdi'' (1955), ''Madira'' (Media) (1955), ''Kishor Natako'' Part 1-2 (1956), ''Kapoorno Deevo'' (1960), ''Param Maheshwar'' (1960), ''Sati'' (1960), ''Karoliyanu Jalu'' (1961), ''Shakuntala Athva Kanyaviday'' (1966), ''Andar Andar'' (1969), ''Abola Rani'' (1972), ''Santakukadi'' (1972), ''Chandravadan Mehtana Pratinidhi Ekankio'' (1974), ''Antar-Bahir Ane Bija Natako'' (1975).<ref name="gsp"/><ref name="ox"/> He extensively wrote on the history of Gujarati theatre and production techniques.<ref name="ox"/> ;Theatre criticism His expertise in theatre and stagecraft as well as his extensive knowledge of international theatre is visible in his works of theatre criticism. He had written eleven works on theatre criticism: ''Kavishri Nanalalna Natako Ane Akbarshahni Rangbhumi Par Rajuat'' (1959), ''Natak Bhajavata'' (1962), ''Lyric'' (1962), ''Lyric Ane Lagarik'' (1965), ''Natyarang'' (1973), ''American Theatre'' (1974), ''Europe na Deshoni Natyashrishti'' (1974), ''Japannu Theatre'' (1975), ''Vak'' (1975), ''Ekanki: Kyare Kya Ane Keva Uprant Bija Natyavishayak Lekho''.<ref name="gsp" />
;Theatre bibliography His ''Bibliography of Stagable Plays in Indian Languages'' Part 1-2 (1964, 1965) is his work of theatre research which received him acclaim in the theatre of Europe. It has an extensive list of plays written and staged in India in the 19th and 20th century arranged according to years, writers and characters. It took ten years to prepare this bibliography.<ref name="gsp"/>
;Poetry ''Yamal'' (1926) is a collection of 14 [[sonnet]]s. ''Elakavyo'' (1933) is 35 sonnets including a reprint of ''Yamal'' and a series of sonnets from ''Kanchanjangha''. ''Chandarana'' (1935) is a collection of children's poetry. ''Ratan'' (1937) is a 1636 stanza long narrative poem in ''Prithvi'' [[metre (poetry)|metre]]. The poem depicts the sacrifice and death of a sister named Ratan. ''Rudo Rabari'' (1940) is his another narrative poem. ''Chado Re Shikhar Raja Ramna'' (1975) has 20 poems including unique poems such as "O New York" and "Colloquial Gujarati Kavita".<ref name="gsp"/> ;Stories ''Khamma Bapu'' (1950) and ''Vatchakaravo'' (1967) are his short story collections. ''Mangalmayi'' (1975) has three true stories. he wrote a novel ''Jeevati Putalio''.<ref name="gsp"/>
;Prose His prose writings include his twelve-volume autobiographical and travel writings, ''Gathariyan'' (Travel Bags) which were in unusual prose and simple language. These volumes are ''Bandh Gathariyan'' Part 1-2 (1954), ''Chhod Gathariyan'' (1956), ''Safar Gathariyan'' (1956), ''Bhamiye Gujarat Na Relpate Na Vate'' (1962), ''Rang Gathariyan'' (1965), ''Roop Gathariyan'' (1965), ''Natya Gathariyan'' (on theatre, 1971), ''Antar Gathariyan'' Part 1-2 (1973), ''Dhruv Gathariyan'' (1976) and ''Ganth Gathariyan'' (1976).<ref name="gsp"/><ref name="ox"/> ;Other works His other works include ''Radio Roopako'', ''Premno Tant'', ''Navbharatna Bhagyavidhata Sardar Vallabhbhaina Jeevan Par Bar Roopako''.<ref name="gsp"/> Mehta had composed the anthem of the [[Maharaja Sayajirao University of Baroda]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.historyofvadodara.in/msu-song/|title=MSU Song {{!}} History of Vadodara - Baroda|date=2016-03-11|work=History of Vadodara - Baroda|access-date=2018-06-11|language=en-US|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161031052234/http://www.historyofvadodara.in/msu-song/|archivedate=31 October 2016|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
==Legacy== In 1960, at Vienna Conference at the [[International Theatre Institute]] under the aegis of [[UNESCO]], he moved a resolution to celebrate 27 March, as the [[World Theatre Day]].<ref name=toi13>{{cite news |title=First Gujarati theatre group came up in 1878 |url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2013-03-27/ahmedabad/38069685_1_parsi-theatre-first-gujarati-world-theatre-day |publisher=The Times of India |date=27 March 2013 |accessdate=14 May 2013}}</ref> Gujarati writer [[Raghuveer Chaudhari]] wrote a play, ''Trijo Purush'', based on his life.<ref name="Te2003" />
==Awards== He received the [[Ranjitram Suvarna Chandrak]] in 1936 and the [[Narmad Suvarna Chandrak]] in 1942. He rejected the [[Kumar Chandrak]] awarded to him in 1950. In 1962, he was awarded the [[Padma Shri]] by the [[Government of India]].<ref name="gsp"/><ref name="Te2003"/>
He won the 1971 [[List of Sahitya Akademi Award winners for Gujarati|Sahitya Akademi Award for Gujarati language]] for his autobiographical travelogue ''Natya Gathariyan''.<ref name="gsp"/><ref name=sahitya>{{cite web | url=http://www.sahitya-akademi.gov.in/old_version/awa10318.htm#gujarati | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090331234109/http://www.sahitya-akademi.gov.in/old_version/awa10318.htm#gujarati | archivedate=31 March 2009 | title=Sanskrit Sahitya Akademi Awards 1955-2007 | publisher=[[Sahitya Akademi]] Official website | deadurl=yes | df= }}</ref> He was also awarded the [[Sangeet Natak Akademi Award]] for [[Sangeet Natak Akademi Award#Playwriting|playwriting in Gujarati]] in 1971.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sangeetnatak.org/sna/awardeeslist.htm |title=SNA: List of Akademi Awardees |publisher=[[Sangeet Natak Akademi]] Official website |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120217185616/http://www.sangeetnatak.org/sna/awardeeslist.htm |archivedate=17 February 2012 |df= }}</ref> In 1984, he was awarded the [[List of Sangeet Natak Akademi fellows|Sangeet Natak Akademi Fellowship]], the highest honour conferred by the [[Sangeet Natak Akademi]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sangeetnatak.gov.in/sna/fellowslist.htm |title=SNA: List of Sangeet Natak Akademi ''Ratna Puraskar''winners (Akademi Fellows) |publisher=Official website |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304023617/http://sangeetnatak.gov.in/sna/fellowslist.htm |archivedate=4 March 2016 |df= }}</ref> He received [[Sahitya Gaurav Puraskar]] for the year 1991.
