revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox film | name = Lost in Translation | image = Lost in Translation poster.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | alt = <!-- description needed see [[WP:ALT]] --> | director = [[Sofia Coppola]] | producer = {{ubl|Sofia Coppola|[[Ross Katz]]}} | writer = Sofia Coppola | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Bill Murray]] * [[Scarlett Johansson]] * [[Giovanni Ribisi]] * [[Anna Faris]] * Fumihiro Hayashi }}<!-- per poster billing block --> | music = [[Kevin Shields]] | cinematography = [[Lance Acord]] | editing = [[Sarah Flack]] | studio = {{ubl|[[American Zoetrope]]|Elemental Films}}<!--PER POSTER BILLING BLOCK--> | distributor = {{ubl|[[Focus Features]] (United States)|[[Tohokushinsha Film]] (Japan)}} | released = {{Film date|2003|8|29|[[Telluride Film Festival]]|2003|9|12|United States|2004|4|17|Japan}} | runtime = 101 minutes<ref>{{cite news | title=''Lost in Translation'' | publisher=Australian Classification | url=http://www.classification.gov.au/Pages/View.aspx?sid=yYswbmSEc6366pg9JjpWng%253d%253d&ncdctx=sHsnaZV38NRshMiU2dzq3nwXWCWJQQkDMMcyOxhF5ce1lVHM9d1FDUiNxfrfQhHHscURO7bmfpScHgp1PojiNw%253d%253d | accessdate=March 14, 2015}}</ref> | country = {{ubl|United States<ref name="afi">{{cite web |url=https://catalog.afi.com/Catalog/moviedetails/54274 |title=Lost in Translation (2003) |format=select "Details" tab |work=[[American Film Institute]] |accessdate=September 9, 2018}}</ref>|Japan<ref name="afi"/>}} | language = {{ubl|English|Japanese}} | budget = $4 million<ref name="boxoffice">{{cite news | title=''Lost in Translation'' | work=Box Office Mojo |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?id=lostintranslation.htm | accessdate=March 13, 2009}}</ref> | gross = $119.7 million<ref name="boxoffice" /> }} '''''Lost in Translation''''' is a 2003 [[Romance film|romantic]] [[comedy-drama]] film written and directed by [[Sofia Coppola]]. It stars [[Bill Murray]] as aging actor Bob Harris, who befriends college graduate Charlotte ([[Scarlett Johansson]]) in a Tokyo hotel.
''Lost in Translation'' was nominated for four [[Academy Awards]], including [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]], [[Academy Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]] for Bill Murray, and [[Academy Award for Best Director|Best Director]] for Coppola; Coppola won for [[Academy Award for Best Original Screenplay|Best Original Screenplay]]. Murray and Johansson each won a [[BAFTA]] award for [[BAFTA Award for Best Actor in a Leading Role|Best Actor in a Leading Role]] and [[BAFTA Award for Best Actress in a Leading Role|Best Actress in a Leading Role]] respectively. The film grossed $119 million on a budget of $4 million.
==Plot== Bob Harris, an aging American movie star, arrives in Tokyo to film an advertisement for [[Suntory]] whisky. Charlotte, a young college graduate, is left in her hotel room by her husband, John, a celebrity photographer on assignment in Tokyo. Charlotte is unsure of her future with John, feeling detached from his lifestyle and disillusioned about their relationship. Bob's own 25-year marriage is strained as he goes through a [[midlife crisis]].
Each day, Bob and Charlotte encounter each other in the hotel, and finally meet at the hotel bar one night when neither can sleep. Eventually, Charlotte invites Bob to meet with some local friends of hers. The two bond through a fun night in Tokyo, welcomed without prejudice by Charlotte's friends and experiencing Japanese nightlife and culture. In the days that follow, Bob and Charlotte's platonic relationship develops as they spend more time together. One night, each unable to sleep, the two share an intimate conversation about Charlotte's personal troubles and Bob's married life.
On the penultimate night of his stay, Bob sleeps with the hotel bar's female jazz singer. The next morning Charlotte arrives at his room to invite him for lunch and overhears the woman in his room, leading to an argument over lunch. Later that night, during a fire alarm at the hotel, Bob and Charlotte reconcile and express how they will miss each other as they make a final visit to the hotel bar.
The following morning, Bob is set to return to the United States. He tells Charlotte goodbye at the hotel lobby and sadly watches her walk back to the elevator. In a taxi to the airport, Bob sees Charlotte on a crowded street and gets out and goes to her. He embraces the tearful Charlotte and whispers something in her ear. The two share a kiss, say goodbye and Bob departs.
==Cast== {{Div col|colwidth=20em}} * [[Bill Murray]] as Bob Harris * [[Scarlett Johansson]] as Charlotte * [[Giovanni Ribisi]] as John * [[Anna Faris]] as Kelly * Fumihiro Hayashi as Charlie Brown * Akiko Takeshita as Ms. Kawasaki * [[François Du Bois]] as the Pianist * [[Takashi Fujii (comedian)|Takashi Fujii]] as TV host * [[Hiromix]] as herself {{div col end}}
==Analysis== Over the course of the film, several things are "lost in translation".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A03E6DD103AF932A1575AC0A9659C8B63 |title=What Else Was Lost in Translation |accessdate=May 2, 2012 |last=Rich |first=Motoko |date=September 21, 2003 |work=[[The New York Times]]|quote= It doesn't take much to figure out that 'Lost in Translation,' the title of Sofia Coppola's elegiac new film about two lonely American souls in Tokyo, means more than one thing. There is the cultural dislocation felt by Bob Harris (Bill Murray), a washed-up movie actor, and Charlotte (Scarlett Johansson), a young wife trying to find herself. They are also lost in their marriages, lost in their lives. As Charlotte says, 'I just feel so alone, even with people around.' Then, of course, there is the simple matter of language.}}</ref> Bob (Murray), a Japanese director ([[Diamond Yukai|Yutaka Tadokoro]]), and an interpreter (Takeshita) are on a set, filming a commercial for [[Suntory]] whisky (specifically, 17-year-old [[Hibiki (whisky)|Hibiki]]). In several exchanges, the director gives lengthy, impassioned directives in Japanese. These are invariably followed by brief, incomplete translations from the interpreter.
::{{dialogue|Director|The translation is very important, O.K.? The translation.|mood1=in Japanese, to the interpreter|Interpreter|Yes, of course. I understand.|mood2=in Japanese, to the director|Director|Mr. Bob. You are sitting quietly in your study. And then there is a bottle of Suntory whisky on top of the table. You understand, right? With wholehearted feeling, slowly, look at the camera, tenderly, and as if you are meeting old friends, say the words. As if you are [[Humphrey Bogart|Bogie]] in ''[[Casablanca (film)|Casablanca]]'', saying, 'Here's looking at you, kid,'—Suntory time!|mood3=in Japanese, to Bob|Interpreter|He wants you to turn, look in camera. O.K.?|mood4=In English, to Bob|Bob|...Is that all he said?}}<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/09/21/style/what-else-was-lost-in-translation.html |title=What Else Was Lost in Translation |accessdate=November 4, 2007 |last=Rich |first=Motoko |date=September 21, 2003 |work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref>
In addition to the meaning and detail lost in the translation of the director's words, the two central characters in the film—Bob and Charlotte—are also lost in other ways. On a basic level, they are lost in the alien [[culture of Japan|Japanese culture]]. But in addition, they are lost in their own lives and relationships, a feeling, amplified by their displaced location, that leads to their blossoming friendship and growing connection with one another.<ref name="Gehring2004">{{cite journal |last=Gehring |first=Wes D. |date=January 2004 |title=Along Comes Another Coppola |journal=[[USA Today (magazine)|USA Today]] |volume=132 |page=59|publisher=The Society for the Advancement of Education |issn=0161-7389}}</ref>
By her own admission, Coppola wanted to create a romantic movie about two characters that have a moment of connection. The story's timeline was intentionally shortened to emphasize this moment.<ref>{{cite journal|date=October 2003|title=The Co-Conspirators|journal=Interview|volume=33|issue=9|page=56|publisher=Interview, Inc.|location=New York|issn=0149-8932}}</ref> Additionally, Coppola has said that since "there's not much happening in the story besides [Bob and Charlotte's relationship]", the filmmakers tried to keep an ongoing tension.<ref name="Carter">{{cite news|title=Famous lost words|first=Kelly|last=Carter|date=September 21, 2003|work=[[South China Morning Post]]}}</ref>
{{Quote box|quote=As an actor, and as a writer/director, the question is: is it going to be very noble here? [Is] this guy going to say, "I just can't call you. We can't share room service anymore?" Is it going to be like that sort of thing, or is it going to be a little more real where they actually get really close to it?|align=right|width=30em|style=padding:8px|source=—Bill Murray<ref name="Murray 1">{{cite web|title=Interview with 'Lost in Translation' Star Bill Murray|url=http://movies.about.com/cs/lostintranslation/a/lostbillint.htm|first=Rebecca|last=Murray|publisher=[[About.com]]|accessdate=Feb 19, 2014|page=1}}</ref>}} Murray has described his biggest challenge in portraying Bob as managing the character's conflicted feelings. On one hand, Murray said, Bob knows that it could be dangerous to become too close to Charlotte, but on the other, he is lonely and knows that having an affair would be easy. Murray worked to portray a balance between being affectionate and being "respectable".<ref name="Murray 1"/>
The academic Marco Abel lists ''Lost in Translation'' as one of many films that belong to the category of "postromance" cinema, which he says offers a negative perspective of love, sex, romance, and dating. According to Abel, the characters in such films reject the idealized notion of lifelong monogamy.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Abel|first=Marco|year=2010|title=Failing to Connect: Itinerations of Desire in Oskar Roehler's Postromance Films|journal=New German Critique|volume=37|issue=1|series=109|page=77|publisher=New German Critique, Inc.|doi=10.1215/0094033X-2009-018}}</ref>
The author and filmmaker Anita Schillhorn van Veen interprets the film as a criticism of [[modernity]], in which Tokyo is a contemporary "[[Ukiyo|floating world]]" of fleeting pleasures that are too alienating and amoral to facilitate meaningful relationships.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Schillhorn van Veen|first=Anita|date=March 1, 2006|title=The Floating World: Representations of Japan in ''Lost in Translation'' and ''Demonlover''|journal=Asian Cinema|volume=17|issue=1|pages=190–193|issn=1059-440X}}</ref> Tessa Dwyer, writing for ''Linguistica Antverpiensia, New Series – Themes in Translation Studies'', called ''Lost in Translation'' a [[Polyglotism|polyglot]] film that challenges the film industry's "more usual tendency to ignore or deny issues of language difference" by highlighting Bob and Charlotte's difficult contact with the Japanese language.<ref name="Dwyer">{{cite journal|last=Dwyer|first=Tessa|year=2005|title=Universally speaking: Lost in Translation and polyglot cinema |url=https://lans-tts.uantwerpen.be/index.php/LANS-TTS/article/view/143 |journal=Linguistica Antverpiensia, New Series – Themes in Translation Studies |issue=4 |pages=297–300 |publisher=Department of Translators and Interpreters, Antwerp University |accessdate=February 25, 2014}}</ref>
===Aesthetics=== The author and lecturer Maria San Filippo contends that the film's setting, Tokyo, is an audiovisual metaphor for Bob and Charlotte's world views. She explains that the calm ambience of the city's hotel represents Bob's desire to be secure and undisturbed, while the energetic atmosphere of the city streets represents Charlotte's willingness to engage with the world.<ref>{{cite journal|last=San Filippo|first=Maria|year=2003|title=Lost in Translation|journal=Cineaste|volume=29|issue=1|page=28|publisher=Cineaste|location=New York|issn=0009-7004}}</ref> Coppola and Acord, the film's cinematographer, agreed that ''Lost in Translation'' needed to rely heavily on visual expression to support the characters' romance.
Robert Hahn, an essayist writing for ''[[The Southern Review]]'', suggested that the filmmakers deliberately used [[chiaroscuro]], the art of using strong contrasts between light and dark to support the story. He wrote that the film's dominant light tones symbolize feelings of humor and romance, and they are contrasted with dark tones that symbolize underlying feelings of despondency. He compared this to the technique of the painter [[John Singer Sargent]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hahn|first=Robert|year=2006|title=Dancing in the Dark|journal=The Southern Review|volume=42|issue=1|pages=153–154|issn=0038-4534}}</ref>
The film's opening shot, which features a close shot of Charlotte sitting in translucent pink underwear, has interested various commentators. In particular, it has been compared to the portraitures of the painter [[John Kacere]] and the image of [[Brigitte Bardot]] in the opening scene of the 1963 film ''[[Contempt (film)|Contempt]]''. Dwyer wrote that when the two shots are compared, they reveal the importance of language difference, as both films highlight the complexities involved with characters speaking multiple languages.<ref name="Dwyer"/> Filippo wrote that while the image in ''Contempt'' is used to remark on [[sexual objectification]], Coppola "doesn't seem to be making a statement at all beyond a sort of endorsement of beauty for beauty's sake".<ref name="San2003">{{cite journal|last=San Filippo|first=Maria|year=2003|title=Lost in Translation |journal=Cineaste |volume=29 |issue=1 |page=26 |publisher=Cineaste |location=New York |issn=0009-7004}}</ref>
Coppola revealed in a 2013 interview that the shot is indeed based on the art of Kacere.<ref name="Stern">{{cite web|title=Sofia Coppola Discusses ‘Lost in Translation’ on Its 10th Anniversary |url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2013/09/12/sofia-coppola-discusses-lost-in-translation-on-its-10th-anniversary.html |first=Marlow|last=Stern |date=September 12, 2013 |work=[[The Daily Beast]]|accessdate=February 20, 2014}}</ref> [[Geoff King]], a professor of film at [[Brunel University]] (who published a book on the film, under the same name in a series titled "American indies", in 2010), contends that the shot is marked by an "obvious" appeal in its potential eroticism, and a "subtle" appeal in its artistic qualities. He used the shot as an example of the film's obvious attractions, which are characteristic of [[Major film studio|mainstream film]], and its subtle ones, which are typified by [[Independent film#The "Indie Film" Movement|"indie" film]].<ref>{{cite book|last=King|first=Geoff|editor=Gary Needham and Yannis Tzioumakis|title=Lost in Translation|series=American Indies|year=2010|publisher=Edinburgh University Press|location=Edinburgh|isbn=9780748637461|pages=1–2|chapter=Introduction}}</ref>
==Production==
===Development=== {{Quote box|quote=I remember having these weeks there that were sort of enchanting and weird ... Tokyo is so disorienting, and there's a loneliness and isolation. Everything is so crazy, and the jet lag is torture. I liked the idea of juxtaposing a midlife crisis with that time in your early 20s when you're, like, What should I do with my life?|align=right|width=30em|style=padding:8px|source=—Sofia Coppola, 2003<ref name="Betts">{{cite news|last=Betts |first=Kate |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1005674-2,00.html |title=Sofia's Choice |publisher=TIME |date=September 15, 2003 |accessdate=April 7, 2012}}</ref>}} Coppola devised the idea of ''Lost in Translation'' after many visits to Tokyo in her twenties, basing much of the story on her experiences there.<ref name="Stern"/><ref name="indiewire">{{cite web|url=http://www.indiewire.com/article/sofia_coppola_talks_about_lost_in_translation_her_love_story_thats_not_nerd |title=Sofia Coppola Talks About "Lost In Translation," Her Love Story That's Not "Nerdy" | Filmmakers, Film Industry, Film Festivals, Awards & Movie Reviews |publisher=Indiewire |date=November 8, 2011 |accessdate=April 7, 2012}}</ref><ref name=autogenerated5>{{cite web|url=http://www.lost-in-translation.com/qaPopup.html |title=Lost In Translation |accessdate=April 7, 2012 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724175933/http://www.lost-in-translation.com/qaPopup.html |archivedate=July 24, 2011 |df= }}</ref> Coppola was attracted to the [[Neon lighting|neon lights]] of [[Tokyo]] and has described the [[Park Hyatt Tokyo]], where most of the film's interior sequences take place, as one of her "favorite places in the world".<ref name="indiewire" /> Particularly, she was attracted to its quietness, design, and "combination of different cultures", which include a New York bar and French restaurant.<ref name="indiewire" />
Coppola spent six months writing the film, beginning with "short stories" and "impressions" that culminated in a 70-page script.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.screenwritersutopia.com/modules.php?name=Content&pa=showpage&pid=57 |title=Sofia Coppola on LOST IN TRANSLATION |publisher=Screenwritersutopia.com |date=March 11, 2004 |accessdate=April 7, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120216010832/http://www.screenwritersutopia.com/modules.php?name=Content&pa=showpage&pid=57 |archivedate=February 16, 2012 |df= }}</ref><ref name="filmmakermagazine">{{cite web |url=http://www.filmmakermagazine.com/issues/fall2003/features/tokyo_story.php |title=Sofia Coppola's Lost in Translation - Filmmaker Magazine - Fall 2003 |publisher=Filmmaker Magazine |accessdate=April 7, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120414022213/http://www.filmmakermagazine.com/issues/fall2003/features/tokyo_story.php |archivedate=April 14, 2012 |df= }}</ref> She wanted to create a story that was "a little more funny and romantic" than her previous feature, ''[[The Virgin Suicides (film)|The Virgin Suicides]]'', and she spent little time planning or rewriting it.<ref name="Carter" /><ref>{{cite journal|last=Chumo|first=Peter N. II|date=January–February 2004|title=Sofia Coppola|journal=Creative Screenwriting|volume=11|issue=1|page=58|issn=1084-8665}}</ref> Coppola has called the film a "valentine" to Tokyo,<ref>{{cite journal|last=Calhoun|first=Dave|year=2003|title=Watching Bill Murray Movies|journal=[[Another Magazine]]|issue=5|page=100|publisher=Dazed Group}}</ref> in which she has displayed the city in the way that it is meaningful to her.
Coppola wrote the film with Murray in mind and said she would not have made it without him.<ref name="Stern"/> She said that she had always wanted to work with Murray and that she was attracted to his "sweet, lovable side".<ref name="indiewire" /> She pursued him for five months to a year, relentlessly sending telephone messages and letters.<ref name="Stern"/><ref name="Betts" /><ref name="nytimes">{{cite news|last=Hirschberg |first=Lynn |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/08/31/magazine/31COPPOLA.html |title=The Coppola Smart Mob |publisher=NYTimes.com |date=August 31, 2003 |accessdate=April 7, 2012}}</ref> She enlisted help from [[Wes Anderson]], who had directed Murray in two films, and screenwriter [[Mitch Glazer]], who was a mutual friend.<ref name="filmmakermagazine" /><ref name="nytimes" /> Coppola went as far to asking for help from actor [[Al Pacino]], who at the time lived in the same town as Murray.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=97jYhz7tmcg|title=Sofia Coppola On Getting Bill Murray To Do LOST IN TRANSLATION|first=|last=American Film Institute|date=December 12, 2008|publisher=|accessdate=August 29, 2017|via=YouTube}}</ref> In July 2002, Coppola and Murray finally met in a restaurant, and he agreed to participate because he "couldn't let her down".<ref name="nytimes" /> Despite this, Murray did not sign a contract; when he finally arrived in Tokyo, Coppola described it as "a huge relief".<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.elle.com/Pop-Culture/Cover-Shoots/Our-Own-Private-Hollywood/Our-Own-Private-Hollywood/%28imageIndex%29/23/%28play%29/false#mode=base;slide=23; |title=26 EL1110 WLWIHSofia 001 |publisher=Elle.com |date=October 7, 2010 |accessdate=April 7, 2012}}</ref>
Coppola first noticed Scarlett Johansson in ''[[Manny & Lo]]'', where she related to her "understated" and "subtle" demeanor,<ref name="filmmakermagazine" /><ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web|url=http://movies.about.com/cs/lostintranslation/a/lostsofia_2.htm|title=Interview with "Lost in Translation" Star Bill Murray|publisher=|accessdate=August 29, 2017}}</ref> envisioning her as a "young [[Lauren Bacall]]-type girl".<ref name="Stern"/> Johansson, who was 17 years old at the time, immediately accepted the part and Coppola was happy with the maturity she brought to the character.<ref name="nytimes" /><ref name=autogenerated1 /> In writing the story, Coppola said she was influenced by the relationship between Humphrey Bogart and [[Lauren Bacall]] in Howard Hawks' ''[[The Big Sleep (1946 film)|The Big Sleep]]''.<ref name="filmmakermagazine" /> Murray and Johansson did not do any auditions before filming.<ref name="Stern"/>
===Filming=== Lance Acord, the film's director of photography, has written that the cinematographic style of ''Lost in Translation'' is largely based on "daily experiences, memories and impressions" of his time in Japan.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Acord|first=Lance|authorlink=Lance Acord|date=January 2004|title=Channeling Tokyo for ''Lost in Translation''|journal=American Cinematographer|volume=85|issue=1|pages=123–124|publisher=American Society of Cinematographers|issn=0002-7928}}</ref> He worked closely with Coppola to visualize the film, relying on multiple experiences he shared with her in Tokyo before production took place. [[Location scouting]] was carried out by Coppola, Acord, and Ross Katz; and Coppola created 40 pages of photographs for the crew so that they would understand her visual intentions.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Chumo|first=Peter N. II|date=January–February 2004|title=Sofia Coppola|journal=Creative Screenwriting|volume=11|issue=1|page=57|issn=1084-8665}}</ref>
Acord sought to maximize [[available light]] during shooting and use [[Stage lighting instrument|artificial lights]] as little as possible. He described this approach as conservative compared to "the more conventional Hollywood system", for which some of the crew's Japanese electricians thought he was "out of his mind".<ref name="Ballinger2004">{{cite book|first=Alex|last=Ballinger|title=New Cinematographers|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=10kR9a9SYnMC&pg=PA16|accessdate=April 6, 2012|date=October 12, 2004|publisher=Laurence King Publishing|isbn=978-1-85669-334-9}}</ref> In particular, Acord did not use any artificial lights to photograph the film's night-time exteriors.<ref name="Ballinger2004" /> ''Lost in Translation'' was largely shot in an improvised, "free-form" manner, which Coppola described as "stealthy" and "almost documentary-style".<ref name="indiewire" /><ref name=autogenerated2>{{cite video|title=Lost in Translation|date=2004|publisher= Focus Features/Universal Studios|medium= DVD}}</ref> The crew shot in some locations without permits, including Tokyo's subways and [[Shibuya, Tokyo#Shibuya Crossing|Shibuya Crossing]]; they avoided police by keeping a minimal crew.<ref name=autogenerated5 /> Acord avoided grandiose camera movements in favor of still shots to avoid taking away from the loneliness of the characters.<ref name="Ballinger2004" />
Most of the film was shot on an [[Aaton]] camera with [[35 mm film|35 mm film stock]], using [[List of motion picture film stocks#VISION color negative (ECN-2 process 1996–2002)|Kodak Vision 500T 5263]] stock for nightlight exteriors and Kodak Vision 320T 5277 stock in daylight. A smaller [[Moviecam Compact]] was used in confined locations. Coppola said that her father, [[Francis Ford Coppola]], tried to convince her to shoot on video, but she ultimately decided on film, describing its "fragmented, dislocated, melancholic, romantic feeling", in contrast with video, which is "more immediate, in the present".<ref name="filmmakermagazine" /> In interviews, she said she wanted to shoot Tokyo with a spontaneous "informality", similar to the "way a snapshot looks", and she chose to shoot on high-speed film stocks to evoke a "homemade intimacy".<ref name="Betts" /><ref name=autogenerated5 /><ref name="filmmakermagazine" /> Some scenes were shot wholly for mood and were captured without sound.<ref name="Betts" />
''Lost in Translation'' was shot six days per week in September and October 2002, over the course of 27 days.<ref name="Betts" /> During this time, videotape footage was mailed to editor Sarah Flack in [[New York City]], where she began editing the film in a Red Car office.<ref name="Crabtree">{{cite journal|last=Crabtree|first=Sheigh|date=September 10, 2003|title=Editor Flack in Fashion for Coppola's "Lost" Pic|journal=The Hollywood Reporter}}</ref> The scenes with Bob and Charlotte together were largely shot in order.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Chumo|first=Peter N. II|date=January–February 2004|title=Sofia Coppola|journal=Creative Screenwriting|volume=11|issue=1|page=64|issn=1084-8665}}</ref> Many of the interior scenes were shot overnight, because the hotel did not allow the crew to shoot in much of its public space until after 1 a.m.<ref name="Ballinger2004" />
Various locations were used during production; in particular, the bar featured prominently in the film is the New York Bar, which is situated on the 52nd floor of the [[Shinjuku Park Tower]] and part of the Park Hyatt in [[Shinjuku, Tokyo]]. Other locations include the [[Heian Jingu]] shrine in [[Kyoto]] and the steps of the San-mon gate at [[Nanzen-ji]], as well as the club Air in the [[Daikanyama]] district of Tokyo. All of the locations mentioned in the film are the names of actual places that existed in Tokyo at the time of filming. Murray described the first few weeks of the shoot as like "being held prisoner", since he was affected by [[jet lag]], and Johansson said the shoot made her "busy, vulnerable and tired".<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2004/jan/01/1 | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Geoffrey | last=MacNab | title=Geoffrey Macnab talks to Bill Murray | date=January 1, 2004}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2003/dec/28/features.magazine | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Polly | last=Vernon | title=Polly Vernon meets Scarlett Johansson | date=January 5, 2004}}</ref>
Coppola spoke of the challenges of directing the movie with a Japanese crew, since she had to rely on her assistant director to make translations.<ref name="indiewire" /> Much of the performances were improvised, and Coppola openly allowed modifications to dialogue during shooting. For example, the dialogue in the scene with Harris and the still photographer was unrehearsed.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Chumo|first=Peter N. II|date=January–February 2004|title=Sofia Coppola|journal=Creative Screenwriting|volume=11|issue=1|pages=58–59|issn=1084-8665}}</ref> Coppola has said that she was attracted to the idea of Bob and Charlotte going through stages of a romantic relationship all in one week—in which they have met, courted, hurt each other, and discussed intimate life. To conclude this relationship, Coppola wanted a special ending even though she thought the concluding scene in the script was mundane. Coppola instructed Murray to perform the kiss in that scene without telling Johansson, to which she reacted without preparation. The whisper was also unscripted, but too quiet to be recorded. While Coppola initially considered having audible dialogue dubbed into the moment, she later decided that it was better to keep it "between the two of them."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Chumo|first=Peter N. II|date=January–February 2004|title=Sofia Coppola|journal=Creative Screenwriting|volume=11|issue=1|pages=63–64|issn=1084-8665}}</ref>
After filming, Coppola and Flack spent approximately 10 weeks editing the film.<ref name="Crabtree" /> In the bonus features of the film's DVD, Murray called ''Lost in Translation'' his favorite film that he has worked on,<ref name=autogenerated2 /> and Coppola described the film as her most "personal", since much of the story is based on her own experiences.<ref name="Stern"/> For example, Charlotte's relationship with her husband is based on Coppola's relationship with her husband, [[Spike Jonze]], when they first married, and the "Suntory" commercial is based on a commercial Coppola's father, [[Francis Ford Coppola]], shot with [[Akira Kurosawa]].<ref name="Stern"/>
===Music=== {{main|Lost in Translation (soundtrack)}} The film's [[Lost in Translation (soundtrack)|soundtrack]], supervised by [[Brian Reitzell]], was released on September 9, 2003 by [[Emperor Norton Records]]. It contains five songs by [[Kevin Shields]], including one from his group [[My Bloody Valentine (band)|My Bloody Valentine]]. Coppola said much of the soundtrack consisted of songs that she "liked and had been listening to", and she worked with Reitzell to make Tokyo [[dream pop]] mixes.<ref name="Stern"/> The soundtrack also included [[The Jesus and Mary Chain]] hit "[[Just Like Honey]]". [[Allmusic]] gave the soundtrack four out of five stars, saying "Coppola's impressionistic romance ''Lost in Translation'' features an equally impressionistic and romantic soundtrack that plays almost as big a role in the film as Bill Murray and Scarlett Johansson do."<ref>{{cite web |last=Phares |first=Heather |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/lost-in-translation-mw0000316244 |title=Lost in Translation – Original Soundtrack |publisher=[[Allmusic]]. [[Rovi Corporation]] |accessdate=October 10, 2010}}</ref>
Agathi Glezakos, an academic writing a review of ''Lost in Translation'' shortly after its release, wrote that the music in the film's karaoke scene constitutes a common "language" that allows Bob and Charlotte to connect with some of the Japanese people amidst their alienation.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Glezakos|first=Agathi|date=October 15, 2003|title=Movie Review: ''Lost in Translation''|journal=Reflections: Narratives of Professional Helping|volume=9|issue=4|pages=71–72|publisher=[[California State University, Long Beach]]|issn=1080-0220}}</ref> In that scene, the rendition of the [[Pretenders (band)|Pretenders]]' "[[Brass in Pocket]]" was selected to showcase a lively side of Charlotte, and "[[(What's So Funny 'Bout) Peace, Love, and Understanding]]" was chosen to establish that Bob is from a different generation. Both Coppola and Murray finally selected [[Roxy Music]]'s "[[More Than This (Roxy Music song)|More Than This]]" during the shoot itself because they liked the band and thought the lyrics fit the story.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Chumo|first=Peter N. II|date=January–February 2004|title=Sofia Coppola|journal=Creative Screenwriting|volume=11|issue=1|pages=60–61|issn=1084-8665}}</ref>
==Reception==
===Box office=== ''Lost in Translation'' was screened at the 2003 [[Telluride Film Festival]].<ref name="mitchell2">{{cite news | last = Mitchell | first = Elvis | authorlink= Elvis Mitchell | title = Telluride Marks Its 30th Year With a Passing of Torches | work = [[The New York Times]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = September 1, 2003 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2003/09/01/movies/critic-s-notebook-telluride-marks-its-30th-year-with-a-passing-of-torches.html | accessdate = March 25, 2009 }}</ref> It was given a limited release on September 12, 2003 in 23 theaters where it grossed $925,087 on its opening weekend with an average of $40,221 per theater and ranking 15th at the box office.<ref name="boxoffice" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the-numbers.com/movies/2003/LSTNT.php |title=Lost in Translation - Box Office Data, Movie News, Cast Information |publisher=The Numbers |accessdate=February 19, 2011}}</ref> It was given a wider release on October 3, 2003 in 864 theaters where it grossed $4,163,333 with an average of $4,818 per theater and ranking 7th. The film went on to make $44,585,453 in [[North America]] and $75,138,403 in the rest of the world for a worldwide total of $119,723,856.<ref name="boxoffice" />
===Critical response=== ''Lost in Translation'' received critical acclaim, particularly for Coppola's direction and screenplay and Murray and Johansson's performances. It has a score of 95% on [[Rotten Tomatoes]], with an average rating of 8.4/10 based on 227 reviews. The site's critical consensus states: "Effectively balancing humor and subtle pathos, Sofia Coppola crafts a moving, melancholy story that serves as a showcase for both Bill Murray and Scarlett Johansson".<ref name="rottentomatoes">{{cite web|title = Lost in Translation|work = Rotten Tomatoes|accessdate = March 19, 2010|url = http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/lost_in_translation/}}</ref> The film also holds a score of 89 out of 100 based on 43 reviews on [[Metacritic]], indicating "universal acclaim".<ref name="metacritic">{{cite web|title=Lost in Translation|work=Metacritic|accessdate=May 25, 2011|url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/lost-in-translation}}</ref>
Critic [[Roger Ebert]] gave ''Lost in Translation'' four out of four stars and named it the second best film of the year, describing it as "sweet and sad at the same time as it is sardonic and funny".<ref name="ebert">{{cite news | last = Ebert | first = Roger | authorlink= Roger Ebert | title = ''Lost in Translation'' | work = [[Chicago Sun-Times]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = September 12, 2003 | url = http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20030912/REVIEWS/309120302/1023 | accessdate = March 16, 2009 }}</ref> In his review for ''[[The New York Times]]'', [[Elvis Mitchell]] wrote: "At 18, [Johansson] gets away with playing a 25-year-old woman by using her husky voice to test the level of acidity in the air ... Ms. Johansson is not nearly as accomplished a performer as Mr. Murray, but Ms. Coppola gets around this by using Charlotte's simplicity and curiosity as keys to her character."<ref name="elvis">{{cite news | last = Mitchell | first = Elvis | authorlink= Elvis Mitchell | title = An American in Japan, Making a Connection | work = [[The New York Times]] | publisher = | date = September 12, 2003 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2003/09/12/movies/film-review-an-american-in-japan-making-a-connection.html | accessdate = March 16, 2009 }}</ref> ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' gave the film an "A" rating and Lisa Schwarzbaum wrote: "Working opposite the embracing, restful serenity of Johansson, Murray reveals something more commanding in his repose than we have ever seen before. Trimmed to a newly muscular, rangy handsomeness and in complete rapport with his character's hard-earned acceptance of life's limitations, Murray turns in a great performance."<ref name="schwarzbaum−">{{cite news | last = Schwarzbaum | first = Lisa | title = ''Lost in Translation'' | work = [[Entertainment Weekly]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = September 10, 2003 | url = http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,479937,00.html | accessdate = March 16, 2009 }}</ref>
In his review for ''[[The New York Observer]]'', [[Andrew Sarris]] called the film "that rarity of rarities, a grown-up romance based on the deliberate repression of sexual gratification ... when independent films are exploding with erotic images edging ever closer to outright pornography, Ms. Coppola and her colleagues have replaced sexual facility with emotional longing, without being too coy or self-congratulatory in the process."<ref name="sarris">{{cite news | last = Sarris | first = Andrew | title = Lonely Souls in a Strange Land: ''Lost in Translation'' Maps the Way | work = [[New York Observer]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = September 28, 2003 | url = http://www.observer.com/node/48113 | accessdate = March 16, 2009 }}</ref> ''[[USA Today]]'' gave the film three and a half stars out of four and wrote that it "offers quiet humor in lieu of the bludgeoning direct assaults most comedies these days inflict".<ref name="clark">{{cite news | last = Clark | first = Mike | title = Comedy doesn't get lost in ''Translation'' | work = [[USA Today]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = September 12, 2003 | url = https://www.usatoday.com/life/movies/reviews/2003-09-11-translation_x.htm | accessdate = March 16, 2009 }}</ref> ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''{{'}}s Richard Corliss praised Murray's performance: "You won't find a subtler, funnier or more poignant performance this year than this quietly astonishing turn."<ref name="corliss">{{cite news | last = Corliss | first = Richard | title = A Victory for Lonely Hearts | work = [[Time (magazine)|Time]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = September 15, 2003 | url = http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,1005675,00.html | accessdate = March 16, 2009 }}</ref> His performance has been likened to the sardonic persona of [[W. C. Fields]].<ref name="Gehring2004" /><ref>{{cite journal|last=Alleva|first=Richard|date=December 5, 2003|title=About a Boy: Kill Bill-Volume 1 and Lost in Translation|journal=[[Commonweal (magazine)|Commonweal]]|volume=130|issue=21|page=14|publisher=Commonweal Foundation|issn=0010-3330}}</ref>
In his review for ''[[The Observer]]'', [[Philip French]] wrote: "While ''Lost in Translation'' is deeply sad and has a strongly [[Michelangelo Antonioni|Antonioniesque]] flavour, it's also a wispy romantic comedy with little plot and some well-observed comic moments."<ref name="french">{{cite news | last = French | first = Philip | authorlink= Philip French | title = The odd Coppola | work = [[The Observer]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = January 11, 2004 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/film/2004/jan/11/philipfrench | accessdate = March 16, 2009 | location=London}}</ref> In ''[[The Guardian]]'', [[Joe Queenan]] praised Coppola's film as "one of the few Hollywood films I have seen this year that has a brain; but more than that, it has a soul."<ref name="queenan">{{cite news | last = Queenan | first = Joe | authorlink= Joe Queenan | title = A yen for romance | work = [[The Guardian]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = January 10, 2004 | url = https://www.theguardian.com/film/2004/jan/10/features.joequeenan | accessdate = March 16, 2009 | location=London}}</ref> ''[[Rolling Stone]]''{{'}}s [[Peter Travers]] gave it four out of four stars and wrote: "Before saying goodbye, they whisper something to each other that the audience can't hear. Coppola keeps her film as hushed and intimate as that whisper. ''Lost in Translation'' is found gold. Funny how a wisp of a movie from a wisp of a girl can wipe you out."<ref name="travers">{{cite news | last = Travers | first = Peter | title = ''Lost in Translation'' | work = [[Rolling Stone]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = September 8, 2003 | url = https://www.rollingstone.com/movies/reviews/lost-in-translation-20030908 | accessdate = March 10, 2011 }}</ref> [[J. Hoberman]], in his review for the ''[[Village Voice]]'', wrote: "''Lost in Translation'' is as bittersweet a brief encounter as any in American movies since [[Richard Linklater]]'s equally romantic ''[[Before Sunrise]]''. But ''Lost in Translation'' is the more poignant reverie. Coppola evokes the emotional intensity of a one-night stand far from home—but what she really gets is the magic of movies".<ref name="hoberman">{{cite news | last = Hoberman | first = J | title = After Sunset | work = [[Village Voice]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = September 9, 2003 | url = http://www.villagevoice.com/2003-09-09/film/after-sunset/1 | accessdate = March 16, 2009 }}</ref>
The [[Los Angeles Film Critics Association]] and [[National Society of Film Critics]] voted Bill Murray best actor of the year.<ref name="Mitchell">{{cite news | last = Mitchell | first = Wendy | title = LA Critics Choose ''Splendor'', ''Friedmans'' Follow-Up, Texas Picks, and More | work = indieWIRE | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = January 9, 2004 | url = http://www.indiewire.com/article/la_critics_choose_splendor_friedmans_follow-up_texas_picks_and_more/ | accessdate = March 13, 2009 }}</ref><ref name="Hernandez4">{{cite news | last = Hernandez | first = Eugene | title = National Film Critics Group Names ''American Splendor'' Top Film of '03 | work = indieWIRE | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = January 5, 2004 | url = http://www.indiewire.com/article/national_film_critics_group_names_american_splendor_top_film_of_03/ | accessdate = March 13, 2009 }}</ref> The [[New York Film Critics Circle]] also voted Murray best actor and Sofia Coppola best director.<ref name="Hernandez5">{{cite news | last = Hernandez | first = Eugene | title = NY Critics Crown ''King'' Top Film of '03; SF & Boston Critics Also Weigh In | work = indieWIRE | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = December 16, 2003 | url = http://www.indiewire.com/article/ny_critics_crown_king_top_film_of_03_sf_boston_critics_also_weigh_in/ | accessdate = March 13, 2009 }}</ref> Coppola received an award for special filmmaking achievement from the [[National Board of Review]].<ref name="Mitchell2">{{cite news | last = Mitchell | first = Wendy | title = National Board of Review Says ''Mystic River'' is Tops For 2003 | work = indieWIRE | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = December 4, 2003 | url = http://www.indiewire.com/article/national_board_of_review_says_mystic_river_is_tops_for_2003/ | accessdate = March 13, 2009 }}</ref> ''Lost in Translation'' also appeared on several critics' top ten lists for 2003.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/film/awards/2003/toptens.shtml|title=Metacritic: 2003 Film Critic Top Ten Lists|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071225093312/http://www.metacritic.com/film/awards/2003/toptens.shtml|archivedate=December 25, 2007|accessdate=March 25, 2009|publisher=[[Metacritic]]}}</ref> [[Roger Ebert]] added it to his "great movies" list on his website.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20100804/REVIEWS08/100809996 | work=Chicago Sun-Times | title=Lost in Translation (2003)}}</ref> ''[[Paste Magazine]]'' named it one of the 50 Best Movies of the Decade (2000-2009), ranking it at #7.<ref>{{cite web|title=The 50 Best Movies of the Decade (2000-2009)|url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/blogs/lists/2009/11/50-best-movies-of-the-decade-2000-2009.html?p=5|work=[[Paste Magazine]]|accessdate=December 14, 2011|date=November 3, 2009}}</ref> ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' named it one of the best films of the decade, writing: "Six years later, we still have no clue what Bill Murray whispered into Scarlett Johansson's ear. And we don't want to. Why spoil a perfect film?"<ref>Geier, Thom; Jensen, Jeff; Jordan, Tina; Lyons, Margaret; Markovitz, Adam; Nashawaty, Chris; Pastorek, Whitney; Rice, Lynette; Rottenberg, Josh; Schwartz, Missy; Slezak, Michael; Snierson, Dan; Stack, Tim; Stroup, Kate; Tucker, Ken; Vary, Adam B.; Vozick-Levinson, Simon; Ward, Kate (December 11, 2009), "THE 100 Greatest MOVIES, TV SHOWS, ALBUMS, BOOKS, CHARACTERS, SCENES, EPISODES, SONGS, DRESSES, MUSIC VIDEOS, AND TRENDS THAT ENTERTAINED US OVER THE PAST 10 YEARS". Entertainment Weekly. (1079/1080):74-84</ref> Director [[Quentin Tarantino]] included ''Lost in Translation'' in his list of top 20 films released since 1992, when his career as a filmmaker began.<ref>{{cite web | title = Team America, Anything Else Among the Best Movies of the Past Seventeen Years, Claims Quentin Tarantino| last=Brown|first=Lane | work=[[New York (magazine)|Vulture]] | publisher=New York Media LLC | url =http://www.vulture.com/2009/08/speed_and_team_america_among_q.html | accessdate=September 13, 2016}}</ref>
In a 2016 international critics' poll by the [[BBC]], ''Lost in Translation'' was voted the 22nd greatest film since 2000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/culture/story/20160819-the-21st-centurys-100-greatest-films |title=The 21st century's 100 greatest films |publisher=BBC |date=August 23, 2016 |accessdate=January 22, 2017}}</ref>
=== Criticism === The film received some negative reviews, many from Japanese critics. Japanese TV critic Osugi {{small|{{bracket|[[:ja:おすぎ|ja]]}}}} of Osugi and [[Peeco|Piko]] fame said "The core story is cute and not bad; however, the depiction of Japanese people is terrible!"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/2004/0419/p07s01-woap.html|title='Lost in Translation' doesn't translate well in Japan|first=Robert|last=Marquand|date=April 19, 2004|publisher=|accessdate=August 29, 2017|via=Christian Science Monitor}}</ref> In a ''Guardian'' article about the film, Kiku Day, a musician specializing in the ''[[shakuhachi]]'' Japanese flute, wrote that she "couldn't help wondering not only whether I had watched a different movie, but whether the plaudits had come from a parallel universe of values"; according to Day, there is "no scene where the Japanese are afforded a shred of dignity. The viewer is sledgehammered into laughing at these small, yellow people and their funny ways."<ref name="kikuguard">{{cite news| url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2004/jan/24/japan.film | title= Totally lost in translation | date= January 24, 2004 | last= Day | first= Kiku | publisher=The Guardian | accessdate= October 10, 2010 | location=London}}</ref> Day also said "while shoe-horning every possible caricature of modern Japan into her movie, Coppola is respectful of ancient Japan. It is depicted approvingly, though ancient traditions have very little to do with the contemporary Japanese. The good Japan, according to this director, is Buddhist monks chanting, ancient temples, [[Ikebana|flower arrangement]]; meanwhile she portrays the contemporary Japanese as ridiculous people who have lost contact with their own culture."<ref name="kikuguard" />
Hawaiian filmmaker and author E. Koohan Paik wrote that "The Japanese are presented not as people, but as clowns" and that "''Lost in Translation'' relies wholly on the "[[Other (philosophy)|other]]ness" of the Japanese to give meaning to its protagonists, shape to its plot, and color to its scenery. The inaccessibility of Japan functions as an extension of the alienation and loneliness Bob and Charlotte feel in their personal lives, thus laying the perfect conditions for romance to germinate: they're the only ones who understand each other. Take away the cartooniness of the Japanese and the humor falls flat, the main characters' intense yearning is neutralized and the plot evaporates."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asianamericanfilm.com/archives/000602.html|title=Asian American Film: Commentary|website=www.asianamericanfilm.com|accessdate=August 29, 2017}}</ref>
In another ''Guardian'' article, journalist David Stubbs described ''Lost in Translation'' as "mopey, self-pitying drivel", and its characters as "spoiled, bored, rich, utterly unsympathetic Americans".<ref>{{cite news| url= https://www.theguardian.com/film/2004/dec/04/culture.features | title= No more heroes: film | date= December 4, 2004 | last= Stubbs | first= David | publisher=The Guardian | accessdate= June 19, 2012 | location=London}}</ref> In an article published in a 2004 issue of ''[[Maclean's]]'', Steve Burgess criticized the film as an ethnocentric "compendium of unpleasant stereotypes ... indicative of the way visitors and foreign workers often view Japan."<ref>{{cite journal|last=Burgess|first=Steve|date=April 26, 2004|title=Found in Translation|journal=[[Maclean's]]|volume=117|issue=17|pages=38–39|publisher=Rogers Communications|issn=0024-9262}}</ref> Robin Antepara, an educator writing for an issue of ''[[Commonweal (magazine)|Commonweal]]'', wrote that while the story embodies stereotypes, "Charlotte is the personification of Japanese watchfulness," an often neglected virtue.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Antepara|first=Robin|date=April 8, 2005|title=Culture Matters: Americans through Japanese Eyes|journal=[[Commonweal (magazine)|Commonweal]]|volume=132|issue=7|pages=10–11|publisher=Commonweal Foundation|issn=0010-3330}}</ref> The academic Maria San Filippo wrote that the "retreat into America-centrism would be disappointing if, again, it were not so truthful ... Coppola knows firsthand that American tourists rarely get to know any Japanese well enough to discover their depth as sympathetic human beings."<ref name="San2003" /> Katz responded to some of the criticism by saying "Sofia's love of Japan and love of the people that she's met there is incredibly evident in the film... Literally, we recounted experiences that I think all of us had gone through," and that none of the scenes were "any slight to Japanese people."<ref>{{cite news|title=Land Of the Rising Cliché|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2004/01/04/movies/land-of-the-rising-cliche.html|first=Motoko|last=Rich|date=January 4, 2004 |author2=Lukas Schwarzacher |author3=Fumie Tomita|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=March 15, 2014}}</ref>
===Accolades=== {{main|List of accolades received by Lost in Translation}} ''Lost in Translation'' won an [[Academy Awards|Oscar]] for [[Academy Award for Writing Original Screenplay|Best Original Screenplay]] in 2003.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.filmsite.org/bestscreenplays4.html |title=Academy Awards Best Screenplays and Writers |publisher=Filmsite.org |accessdate=February 19, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boxofficeprophets.com/awards/display.cfm?awardsaxID=16&awardsyear=2003 |title=Box Office Prophets Film Awards Database: Best Adapted Screenplay 2003 |publisher=Boxofficeprophets.com |accessdate=February 19, 2011}}</ref> It was also nominated for [[Academy Award for Best Director|Best Director]] and [[Academy Award for Best Picture|Best Picture]], but lost both to ''[[The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King]]''. Bill Murray was also nominated for [[Academy Award for Best Actor|Best Actor]], but lost to [[Sean Penn]] for ''[[Mystic River (film)|Mystic River]]''.
The film won [[Golden Globe Awards|Golden Globes]] for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Motion Picture - Musical or Comedy|Best Musical or Comedy Motion Picture]], [[Golden Globe Award for Best Screenplay|Best Screenplay]], and [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actor - Motion Picture Musical or Comedy#2000s|Best Musical or Comedy Actor]]. It was also nominated for [[Golden Globe Award for Best Director - Motion Picture|Best Director]], and [[Golden Globe Award for Best Actress - Motion Picture Musical or Comedy|Best Musical or Comedy Actress]].<ref name="Hernandez3">{{cite news | last = Hernandez | first = Eugene | title = ''Lord of the Rings'' and ''Lost in Translation'' Big Winners at Golden Globes | work = indieWIRE | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = January 26, 2004 | url = http://www.indiewire.com/article/lord_of_the_rings_and_lost_in_translation_big_winners_at_golden_globes/ | accessdate = March 13, 2009 }}</ref>
At the [[British Academy of Film and Television Arts|BAFTA]] film awards, ''Lost in Translation'' won the Best Editing, [[BAFTA Award for Best Actor in a Leading Role|Best Actor]] and [[BAFTA Award for Best Actress in a Leading Role#Winners 1968-present|Best Actress]] awards. It was also nominated for best film, director, original screenplay, music and cinematography. It won four [[IFP Independent Spirit Awards]], for Best Feature, Director, Male Lead, and Screenplay.<ref name="Hernandez">{{cite news | last = Hernandez | first = Eugene | title = ''Lost In Translation'' Tops Independent Spirit Awards, ''Station Agent'' Another Big Winner | work = indieWIRE | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = February 28, 2004 | url = http://www.indiewire.com/article/lost_in_translation_tops_independent_spirit_awards_station_agent_another_bi/ | accessdate = March 13, 2009 }}</ref> The film was honored with the original screenplay award from the [[Writers Guild of America]].<ref name="Hernandez2">{{cite news | last = Hernandez | first = Eugene | title = WGA Opts for ''Translation'' and ''Splendor'', While SAG Goes for ''Rings'' | work = indieWIRE | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = February 23, 2004 | url = http://www.indiewire.com/article/wga_opts_for_translation_and_splendor_while_sag_goes_for_rings/ | accessdate = March 13, 2009 }}</ref>
==Release== ''Lost in Translation'' was released on DVD on February 3, 2004.<ref name="metacritic" /><ref>{{cite web|first= Andy|last= Patrizio |url=http://dvd.ign.com/articles/489/489848p1.html |title=Lost in Translation - DVD Review at IGN |publisher=Dvd.ign.com |date=February 3, 2004 |accessdate=February 19, 2011}}</ref> ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' gave it an "A" rating and criticized "the disc's slim bonus features", but praised the film for standing "on its own as a valentine to the mysteries of attraction".<ref name="fonseca">{{cite news | last = Fonseca | first = Nicholas | title = ''Lost in Translation'' | work = [[Entertainment Weekly]] | pages = | language = | publisher = | date = February 13, 2004 | url = http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,588239,00.html | accessdate = March 16, 2009 }}</ref>
''Lost in Translation'' was also released in high definition on the now defunct [[HD DVD]] format. A [[Blu-ray]] edition was released on January 4, 2011.<ref>[http://www.highdefdigest.com/news/show/Disc_Announcements/Universal/Lost_in_Translation_Blu-ray_Detailed_and_Delayed/5513 'Lost in Translation' Blu-ray Detailed and Delayed], a September 30, 2010 article from High-Def Digest</ref>

{{Infobox person |name = Marilyn Frye |birth_date = {{birth year and age|1941}} |birth_place = [[Tulsa, Oklahoma]], U.S. |death_date = |death_place = |education = [[Stanford University]] {{small|([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]])}}
[[Cornell University]] {{small|([[Master of Arts|MA]], [[Doctor of Philosophy|PhD]])}} }} '''Marilyn Frye''' (born 1941 in [[Tulsa]], [[Oklahoma]]) is an American philosopher and [[radical feminist|radical feminist theorist]]. She is known for her theories on [[sexism]], [[racism]], [[oppression]], and sexuality. Her writings offer discussions of feminist topics, such as: [[white supremacy]], [[male privilege]], and gay and lesbian [[marginalization]]. Although she approaches the issues from the perspective of justice, she is also deeply engaged with the [[metaphysics]], [[epistemology]], and [[moral psychology]] of social categories. ==Education and career== Frye received the BA with honors in philosophy from [[Stanford University]] in 1963 and received the PhD in Philosophy at [[Cornell University]] in 1969, writing a dissertation titled "Meaning and Illocutionary Force," under the supervision of [[Max Black]]. Before coming to [[Michigan State University]] in 1974, she taught in the Philosophy Department at the [[University of Pittsburgh]]. From 2003 until her retirement, Frye was University Distinguished Professor at [[Michigan State University]]; she also served as Associate Dean for Graduate Studies of the College of Arts and Letters. In 2008 she was the [[Phi Beta Kappa Society|Phi Beta Kappa]] Romanell Lecturer. ==Research and publications== Frye is the author of ''[[The Politics of Reality]]''Frye, Marilyn. The Politics of Reality: Essays in Feminist Theory, The Crossing Press, 1983, {{ISBN|0-89594-099-X}}, p175 (1983), a collection of nine essays which has become a "classic" of feminist philosophy.{{cite journal|last=Cudd|first=Ann|title=Frye, Marilyn (1941-)|journal=Encyclopedia of Philosophy|year=2006}} In her chapter entitled "Oppression" in the book ''Feminist Frontiers'', Frye discusses the idea of the [[double bind]] in gender. This double bind refers to "situations in which options are reduced to a very few and all of them expose one to penalty, censure or deprivation". Frye applies this principle to gender and the dilemma women often face in her discussion of oppression. For example, it is neither socially acceptable for a women to be sexually active or for her to be sexually inactive and labelled a "man-hater" or "uptight". This absence of choice permeates so thoroughly into women's day-to-day life that even small things like how they choose to dress or talk are criticized. Frye acknowledges that men face issues as well, but differentiates the issues of men and women through the metaphor of a bird cage. Each individual bind women face can be thought of as a single bar in a cage: by itself, it isn't enough to contain the bird. But, with enough bars, the bird is trapped inside the cage, left with nowhere to go. This is the complete absence of choice Frye describes: how it is the culmination of issues women face that is so "immobilizing" and why their struggle, and not men's, is considered [[oppression]].{{Cite book|title=Feminist Frontiers|last=Frye|first=Marilyn|publisher=|year=2007|isbn=|edition=7th|location=|pages=7–9|chapter=Oppression}} Frye is openly [[lesbian]],''[[Willful Virgin: Essays in Feminism, 1976-1992]]'' (1992) and much of her work explores social categories—in particular, those based on [[Race (classification of human beings)|race]] and [[gender]].[http://www.cal.msu.edu/departments/Frye.php MSU Philosopher Marilyn Frye Wins Romanell-Phi Beta Kappa Professorship] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070815162502/http://www.cal.msu.edu/departments/Frye.php |date=2007-08-15 }} accessed June 21, (2007){{cite journal|last=Cutbank|first=Kid|title=Book Review: Frye's Politics of Reality|journal=[http://kidcutbank.blogspot.com/2012/05/book-review-politics-of-reality-by.html KidCutbank] Blog|year=2012}}{{cite journal|last=Card|first=Claudia|title=Oppression and Resistance: Frye's Politics of Reality|journal=Hypatia|year=1986|volume=1|issue=1|pages=149–166|doi=10.1111/j.1527-2001.1986.tb00526.x}} ==Awards and distinctions== *Frye was named Distinguished Woman Philosopher of the Year[http://cswip.ca/index.php/events/295/ Distinguished Woman Philosopher of the Year] by the [[Society for Women in Philosophy]] in 2001.[http://www.msu.edu/unit/wmstdy/wsnl_spring992.htm MSU Women’s Studies Newsletter Spring 2000] accessed June 21, 2007 *Frye was chosen as [[Phi Beta Kappa]]'s Romanell Professor in Philosophy for 2007-2008. The annually-awarded Romanell Professorship "recognizes the recipient's distinguished achievement and substantial contribution to the public understanding of philosophy." Recipients of this award also offer a series of lectures open to the public; Frye's series was entitled "Kinds of People: Ontology and Politics."[http://staging.pbk.org/AM/Template.cfm?Section=News3&Template=/CM/ContentDisplay.cfm&ContentID=2271 Phi Beta Kappa Society '07 Romanell Professor] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070519004604/http://staging.pbk.org/AM/Template.cfm?Section=News3&Template=%2FCM%2FContentDisplay.cfm&ContentID=2271 |date=2007-05-19 }} accessed June 21, (2007) ==Bibliography== === Books === * {{cite book | last = Frye | first = Marilyn | title = [[The Politics of Reality|The politics of reality: essays in feminist theory]] | publisher = Crossing Press | location = Trumansburg, New York | year = 1983 | isbn = 9780895940995 }} * {{cite book | last = Frye | first = Marilyn | title = Willful virgin: essays in feminism, 1976-1992 | publisher = Crossing Press | location = Freedom, California | year = 1992 | isbn = 9780895945532 }} * {{cite book | last1 = Frye | first1 = Marilyn | last2 = Hoagland | first2 = Sarah Lucia | author-link2 = Sarah Hoagland | title = Feminist interpretations of Mary Daly | publisher = Pennsylvania State University | series = Re-reading the cannon | location = University Park, Pennsylvania | year = 2000 | isbn = 9780271020198 }} === Chapters in books === * "Categories and Dichotomies", ''Encyclopedia of Feminist Theories'', ed., Loraine Code, NY: Routledge, (2000) * "Essentialism/Ethnocentrism: The Failure of the Ontological Cure", ''Is Academic Feminism Dead? Theory in Practice,'' ed., the Center for Advanced Feminist Studies at the University of Minnesota, NYU Press, (2000) * {{citation | last = Frye | first = Marilyn | contribution = Oppression | editor-last1 = Cudd | editor-first1 = Ann E. | editor-last2 = Andreasen | editor-first2 = Robin O. | editor-link1 = Ann Cudd | title = Feminist theory: a philosophical anthology | publisher = Blackwell Pub | pages = 84–90 | location = Oxford, UK Malden, Massachusetts | year = 2005 | isbn = 9781405116619 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} * {{citation | last = Frye | first = Marilyn | contribution = Categories in distress | editor-last1 = Andrew | editor-first1 = Barbara S. | editor-last2 = Keller | editor-first2 = Jean | editor-last3 = Schwartzman | editor-first3 = Lisa H. | title = Feminist interventions in ethics and politics: feminist ethics and social theory | publisher = Rowman & Littlefield Publishers | pages = 41–58 | location = Lanham, Maryland | year = 2005 | isbn = 9780742542693 | ref = harv | postscript = .}} === Journal articles === * "The Necessity of Differences: Constructing a Positive Category of Women," ''SIGNS: Journal of Women in Culture and Society,'' Vol.21, No.3, Summer (1996) ==See also== *[[American philosophy]] *[[List of American philosophers]] ==References== == External links== {{Wikiquote}} * {{Infobox officeholder |name = Marta Canessa |image = |office = [[First Lady of Uruguay]] |term_start = March 1, 1995 |term_end = March 1, 2000 |predecessor = [[Julia Pou]] |successor = [[Mercedes Menafra]] |president = [[Julio María Sanguinetti]] |office1 = [[First Lady of Uruguay]] |term_start1 = March 1, 1985 |term_end1 = March 1, 1990 |predecessor1= [[Alicia Rey Nebril]] |successor1 = [[Julia Pou]] |president1 = [[Julio María Sanguinetti]] |birth_date = {{birth date|1936|12|16}} |birth_place = [[Montevideo]], [[Uruguay]] |death_date = |death_place = |party = |alma_mater = |occupation = [[Historian]]
Academic
Journalist
Writer |residence = |spouse = [[Julio María Sanguinetti]] |children = Julio Luis
Emma |mother = [[María de Montserrat]] }} '''Marta Canessa''' (born December 16, 1936 [[Montevideo]]) is a Uruguayan [[historian]], academic and writer. Canessa, the wife of former [[President of Uruguay|President]] [[Julio María Sanguinetti]], served as the [[First Lady of Uruguay]] for two non-consecutive terms - 1985 to 1990 and 1995 until 2000. ==Biography== Canessa was member of the Commission special permanent of the city old in Montevideo during 15 years. Also was member of the Council honorary of them works of preservation and reconstruction of it Cologne of the Sacramento, which was later declared heritage of the humanity by it [[Unesco]].http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/747 ==Personal life== She is the daughter of [[María de Montserrat]], a writer. ==Selected work== *''Rivera: un Oriental Liso y Llano'' ([[Ediciones de la Banda Oriental]], Montevideo. 1976) *''Ciudad Vieja de Montevideo'' *''El Bien Nacer. Limpieza de Oficios y Limpieza de Sangre. Raíces Ibéricas de un Mal Latinoamericano''. Montevideo, Alfaguara, 2000. ==References== {{reflist}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Canessa, Martha}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1936 births]] [[Category:People from Montevideo]] [[Category:Uruguayan women essayists]] [[Category:Uruguayan historians]] [[Category:Spanish-language writers]] [[Category:First Ladies of Uruguay]] [[Category:Julio María Sanguinetti]] {{Uruguay-historian-stub}}

revision.comment: rv, overly narrow transcription and not covered in source
Successfully de-orphaned! Wikiproject Orphanage: [[Wikipedia:ORPHAN|You can help!]]

I clarified the claim that Nenets has 16 moods by summarizing a bit of the citation given - if you are used to thinking of moods as being as distinct in their use as "is" vs "be!" vs "would be," then having 16 moods seems like a pretty radical thing, but really what is going on here is "is" vs "definitely is" vs "probably is" vs "seems to be." I also narrowed the claim to Tundra Nenets, because the citation only mentions Tundra and the number doesn't seem likely to be the same for both.
revision.text:
{{distinguish|Enets language}} {{Infobox language |name = Nenets |state = Russia |region = [[Nenets Autonomous Okrug]], [[Yamalo-Nenets Autonomous Okrug]], [[Krasnoyarsk Krai]], [[Komi Republic]], [[Murmansk Oblast]]{{Citation needed|date=January 2010}} |ethnicity = 44,600 [[Nenets people]] (2010 census)<ref name=e18>{{Ethnologue18|yrk}}</ref> |speakers = 21,926 |date = 2010 census |ref = <ref>{{Cite web|url=[http://www.gks.ru/free_doc/new_site/perepis2010/croc/Documents/Vol4/pub-04-05.pdf Перепись-2010]|title=Population of the Russian Federation by Languages (in Russian)|last=|first=|date=|website=gks.ru|publisher=Russian Bureau of Statistics|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=1 November 2017}}</ref> |familycolor = Uralic |fam2 = [[Samoyedic languages|Samoyedic]] |fam3 = (core) |fam4 = [[Enets language|Enets]]–Nenets |dia1 = [[Forest Nenets language|Forest Nenets]] |dia2 = [[Tundra Nenets language|Tundra Nenets]] |iso3 = yrk |glotto=nene1249 |glottorefname=Nenets }}
'''Nenets''' (in former work also '''Yurak''') is a pair of closely related languages spoken in northern [[Russia]] by the [[Nenets people]]. They are often treated as being two [[dialect]]s of the same language, but they are very different and [[mutual intelligibility]] is low. The languages are [[Tundra Nenets language|Tundra Nenets]], the bigger language of the two in number of speakers, spoken by some 30,000 to 40,000 people<ref name="ethnologue">{{cite web|url=http://www.ethnologue.com/show_language.asp?code=yrk|title=Nenets|author=|date=|website=ethnologue.com|accessdate=20 April 2018}}</ref><ref name="brown2006">{{cite book | author = [[Tapani Salminen|Salminen, Tapani]], [[Farrell Ackerman|Ackerman, Farrell]] | editor = [[Keith Brown (linguist)|Brown, Keith]] | year = 2006 | pages = 577–579 | chapter = Nenets | title = Encyclopedia of Languages & Linguistics | edition = 2 | volume = 8 | publisher = [[Elsevier]] | location = [[Oxford]], [[England]]}}</ref> in an area stretching from the [[Kanin Peninsula]] to the [[Yenisei River]];<ref name="staroverov2006">{{cite book | author = [[Peter Staroverov|Staroverov, Peter]] | location = [[Moscow]], [[Russia]] | year = 2006 | title = Vowel deletion and stress in Tundra Nenets | page = 1}}</ref> and [[Forest Nenets language|Forest Nenets]], spoken by 1,000 to 1,500 people around the [[Agan River|Agan]], [[Pur River (Russia)|Pur]], [[Lyamin River|Lyamin]] and [[Nadym River|Nadym rivers]].<ref name="ethnologue" /><ref name="brown2006" />
The Nenets languages are classified in the [[Uralic languages|Uralic language family]], making them distantly related to some national languages spoken in Europe – namely [[Finnish language|Finnish]], [[Estonian language|Estonian]], and [[Hungarian language|Hungarian]] – in addition to other minority languages spoken in Russia. Both of the Nenets languages have been greatly influenced by [[Russian language|Russian]]. [[Tundra Nenets language|Tundra Nenets]] has, to a lesser degree, been influenced by [[Komi language|Komi]], and [[Khanty language|Northern Khanty]]. [[Forest Nenets language|Forest Nenets]] has also been influenced by [[Khanty language|Eastern Khanty]]. Tundra Nenets is well documented, considering its status as an [[indigenous language|indigenous]] and [[minority language]], also having a literary tradition going back to the 1930s, while Forest Nenets was first written during the 1990s and is only very little documented.<ref name="brown2006" />
Apart from the word 'Nenets', only one other Nenets word has entered the [[English language]]: '[[parka]]', their traditional long hooded jacket made from skins and sometimes fur.<ref>[http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/parka "parka" in ''Merriam-Webster Online Dictionary'']</ref><ref name="games2007">{{Cite book | author = [[Alex Games|Games, Alex]] | year = 2007 | title = Balderdash & Piffle: One Sandwich Short of a Dog's Dinner | isbn = 978-1-84607-235-2 | publisher = [[BBC]] | location = [[London]]}}{{Verify credibility|date=January 2010}}</ref>
== Common features of Nenets languages == Tundra Nenets has 16 [[Grammatical mood|moods]], most of which reflect different degrees of certainty in what in English might be called [[Realis mood|indicative]] statements or different degrees of force in what in English might be called [[Imperative mood|imperative]] commands.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/sketch.html|title=Tundra Nenets grammatical sketch|author=|date=|website=www.helsinki.fi|accessdate=20 April 2018}}</ref> An overarching feature of the Nenets languages is the introduction of systematic [[Palatalization (phonetics)|palatalization]] of almost all consonants. This originates from contrasts between different vowel qualities in the [[Proto-Samoyedic]] language.<ref name = "Sml88">{{citation | last = Sammallahti | first = Pekka | author-link = Pekka Sammallahti | year = 1988 | chapter = Historical phonology of the Uralic languages, with special reference to Samoyed, Ugric, and Permic | title = The Uralic Languages: Description, History and Foreign Influences | editor-link = Denis Sinor | pages = 478–554 | publisher = Brill | publication-place = Leiden }}</ref> * *Cä, *Ca → *Cʲa, *Ca * *Ce, *Cë → *Cʲe, *Ce * *Ci, *Cï → *Cʲi, *Ci * *Cö, *Co → *Cʲo, *Co * *Cü, *Cu → *Cʲu, *Cu The [[velar consonant]]s *k and *ŋ were additionally shifted to *sʲ and *nʲ when palatalized.
Similar changes have also occurred in the other Samoyedic languages spoken in the tundra zone: [[Enets language|Enets]], [[Nganasan language|Nganasan]] and the extinct [[Yurats language|Yurats]].
== Differences between Tundra and Forest Nenets ==
Tundra Nenets generally has remained closer to Proto-Nenets than Forest Nenets, whose phonology has been influenced by eastern [[Khanty language|Khanty]] dialects. Changes towards the modern languages include:<ref name="SalmNotes">{{citation | last = Salminen | first = Tapani | year = 2007 | issue = 253 | title = Notes on Forest Nenets phonology | journal = Mémoires de la Société Finno-Ougrienne | url = http://www.sgr.fi/sust/sust253/sust253_salminen.pdf | location = [[Helsinki]], [[Finland]] | publisher = [[Suomalais-Ugrilainen Seura]]}}</ref><ref name = "Sml88"/> * Tundra Nenets: ** Delabialization of /wʲ/ → /j/ ** Lenition of initial /k/ → /x/ ** Simplification of /ʔk/ → /k/ * Forest Nenets: ** Initial /s/ → /x/ ** Medial denasalization of /nʲ/ → /j/ ** The change of rhotics to lateral fricatives: /r/, /rʲ/ → /ɬ/, /ɬʲ/ ** Shortening of geminate nasals ** Breaking of geminate /lː/ → /nɬ/ ** Phonemicization of palatalized velars /kʲ/, /xʲ/, /ŋʲ/ due to vowel changes ** Raising of non-close vowels preceding a syllable with an original close vowel ** Loss of vowel distinctions in unstressed syllables ** Introduction of short/long contrasts for /a/ and /æ/
== References == === Note === {{reflist}}
== External links == {{Incubator|code= yrk}} * [http://www.helsinki.fi/~tasalmin/tn.html Tundra Nenets website] * [https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http://www.geocities.com/Vienna/3259/fnen-eng.html&date=2009-10-25+11:37:42 Forest Nenets – English glossary] * [http://www.speech.nw.ru/Nenets/ The Russian–Nenets Audio Phrasebook] * [http://www.speech.nw.ru/NenNgan/ Comparative Nenets–Nganasan dictionary (with Russian and English equivalents)]
{{Uralic languages}}
